    Structurally Strained Half-Sandwich Iridium(III) Complexes As Highly Potent Anticancer Agents

    • Ana C. Carrasco
      Ana C. Carrasco
      IMDEA Nanociencia, Faraday 9, 28049 Madrid, Spain
      More by Ana C. Carrasco
      • , 
    • Vanessa Rodríguez-Fanjul
      Vanessa Rodríguez-Fanjul
      IMDEA Nanociencia, Faraday 9, 28049 Madrid, Spain
      More by Vanessa Rodríguez-Fanjul
      http://orcid.org/0000-0002-3386-5874
      • , 
    • Abraha Habtemariam
      Abraha Habtemariam
      IMDEA Nanociencia, Faraday 9, 28049 Madrid, Spain
      Department of Chemistry, University of Warwick, Gibbet Hill Road, Coventry CV4 7AL, U.K.

      • , and

      More by Ana M. Pizarro
      http://orcid.org/0000-0003-3037-9835
    Cite this: J. Med. Chem. 2020, 63, 8, 4005–4021

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Six complexes of formula [Ir(η5:κ1-C5Me4CH2py)(C,N)]PF6, where C5Me4CH2py is 2-((2,3,4,5-tetramethylcyclopentadienyl)methyl)pyridine, and C,N is 2-phenylpyridine (1), 7,8-benzoquinoline (2), 1-phenylisoquinoline (3), 2-(p-tolyl)pyridine (4), 4-chloro-2-phenylquinoline (5), or 2-(2,4-difluorophenyl)pyridine (6), have been synthesized. The cyclopentadienyl ligand bears a tethered pyridine that binds to the metal center, resulting in an Ir(η5:κ1-C5Me4CH2pyN) tether-ring structure, as confirmed by the X-ray crystal structures of 1, 2, 4, 5, and 6. Nontether versions of 1 and 2 were synthesized to aid unambiguous correlation between structure and activity. While nontether complexes are highly potent toward MCF7 cancer cells (similar to cisplatin), complexes bearing the tether-ring structure, 1–6, are exceptionally more potent (1–2 orders of magnitude). Additionally, 1–6 disrupt mitochondrial membrane potential (ΔΨm) and induce oxidative stress. Internalization studies strongly correlate intracellular accumulation and anticancer activity in tether and nontether complexes. We present a new class of organo-iridium drug candidates bearing a structural feature that results in a leap in anticancer potency.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Interest in bioinorganic chemistry inspired by the clinical success of cisplatin has contributed to the fast development of new organometallic compounds with biological applications.(1) In the past decade, a number of studies of both cyclometalated and half-sandwich cyclopentadienyl iridium(III) compounds have reported that such organo-iridium complexes exhibit promising anticancer activity.(2)
    Our understanding of the mechanism of action of iridium-based metallodrug candidates is in constant development, and studies on drug accumulation and localization are mandatory in this endeavor.(3) Iridium metallodrugs have been reported to target different organelles, from the endoplasmic reticulum(4) to the lysosomes.(5) The mitochondria is also a likely target because its polarized membrane attracts and retains lipophilic cations, the latter defined by criteria that organo-iridium compounds often fulfill.(6) Importantly, cancer cells have an unusually high mitochondrial membrane potential,(7) which contributes to the interest of mitochondria as intracellular targets in cancer research.(8) Mitochondria and mitochondrial metabolism plasticity are essential in tumor initiation, in sustaining the growth and survival of cancer cells, as well as in the cancer cell response to treatment.(9) They are the major intracellular source of reactive oxygen species (ROS), which in turn are involved in signaling cell growth and differentiation at low and moderate doses, while a severe increase of ROS can induce irreversible oxidative damage of cellular components and trigger cell death.(10) Excess ROS is closely related to mitochondrial membrane potential dissipation, and both are associated with the induction of regulated cell death (RCD) in cancer cells.(11) Mitochondria-driven cell death has emerged as a very appealing goal: causing mitochondria dysfunction and ROS overproduction has proved incompatible with tumor progression.(9) Iridium(III) cyclopentadienyl complexes are known to target the intracellular redox balance, particularly sensitive in cancer cells,(12) by generating an excessive level of ROS and thus driving the cancer cell to death.(2b,13)
    Following a rational design aimed at increasing the anticancer activity of Ir(III) complexes of general formula [Ir(η5-C5Me4R)(XY)Cl]0/+, Sadler and co-workers have investigated the correlation between anticancer potency and structure.(14) Modification of the electronic properties of the iridium center by varying the different ligands around it can help fine-tune both the chemical and biological activities of Ir-Cp compounds. The introduction of phenyl rings on the cyclopentadienyl ligand (R = phenyl or biphenyl),(15) the use of anionic C,N-chelating ligands (XY = phenylpyridine),(16) and replacement of the chlorido ligand by a pyridine(13a,17) have resulted in complexes with submicromolar anticancer activity in a number of cancer cells lines. Liu has explored an array of complexes bearing a variety of XY ligands, including imine-N-heterocyclic carbenes,(18) phenoxide N-heterocyclic carbenes,(19) and phosphine-imine,(5b) achieving cytotoxic potency as good as that of cisplatin (in the micromolar range). Additional exploration of the modification of the η5-C5Me4R moiety have been investigated by McGowan, who has derivatized the cyclopentadienyl ligand with different-length terminal alcohols(20) and amines.(21)
    We and others have previously used derivatized arenes bearing a functional tethering group in Ru(II)–arene complexes capable of κ-binding to the metal center, thereby creating a switch (labile bond in the time frame of the desired reaction) for selective activation, whether for biological or other applications such as catalysis.(22) Iridium complexes bearing Cp functionalized with tethering ligands (e.g., containing coordinating nitrogen, phosphorus or oxygen), capable of chelation, have also been explored for catalytic transformations such as reductive amination,(23) dehalogenation,(23) stereoselective C–H activation,(24) and transfer hydrogenation reactions.(23,25)
    Here we report a series of pyridine-tethered iridium(III)-cyclopentadienyl complexes of formula [Ir(η:5κ1-C5Me4CH2py)(C,N)]PF6, bearing: (i) a derivative of a C,N-binding 2-phenylpyridine or 7,8-benzoquinoline bidentate ligand, and (ii) a tether ring formed by the binding of ligand η5-C5Me4CH2pyridine-κN to the Ir(III) metal center, resulting in a doubly chelated organo-iridium structure. In comparison to previously reported Ir(III)-Cp anticancer candidates, the central iridium atom in these complexes lacks a monodentate ligand, known as the “leaving group”, in its first coordination sphere. However, the chelate formed by η5-C5Me4CH2pyridine-κN could behave as hemilabile, providing our system with the capability of activation. We have investigated the reversible opening and closure dynamics of the hemilabile chelate ring against nucleophiles such as DMSO and water. The tether ring is open in pure DMSO, affording the κ-bound DMSO adduct. However, the chelate readily closes upon dissolution in aqueous solution, reversing to the initial closed-tether structure.
    In vitro assays in cancer cells revealed an extraordinary potent activity of our tethered pyridine complexes, with IC50 values in the nanomolar range. To better understand the role of the extra tether ring on the new compounds’ biological activity, we have synthesized and investigated also nontether analogues, i.e., similar complexes regarding the first coordination sphere of the complex yet lacking the additional tether ring. Guided by results recently reported by our group for complex 1, which displays unambiguous and exclusive localization in the mitochondria of MCF7 cells,(26) we studied the loss of mitochondrial transmembrane potential (ΔΨm) and generation of ROS, processes that can be linked to mitochondrial targeting and to cell death by disrupting the intracellular redox homeostasis. Finally, we have investigated iridium accumulation in cancer cells, finding that exceptionally high compound internalization might explain the great potency of this class of organo-iridium anticancer candidates.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Synthesis and Characterization

    Thirteen iridium(III) cyclopentadienyl complexes with typical half-sandwich structure were synthesized and are shown in Chart 1. The synthesis of complex 1 has been recently reported by us.(26)
    Complexes 1–6, of general formula [Ir(η5:κ1-C5Me4CH2py)(C,N)]PF6 (C5Me4CH2py = 2-((2,3,4,5-tetramethylcyclopentadienyl)methyl)pyridine), where C,N is 2-phenylpyridine, Phpy (1), 7,8-benzoquinoline, Bzq (2), 1-phenylisoquinoline, Phq (3), 2-(p-tolyl)pyridine, MePhpy (4), 4-chloro-2-phenylquinoline, ClPhq (5), and 2-(2,4-difluorophenyl)pyridine, dFPhpy (6), were synthesized by aquation of the dichlorido monomer [Ir(η5:κ1-C5Me4CH2py)Cl2] by chloride sequestration with silver nitrate, adapting a reported procedure.(23) Subsequent addition of the corresponding ancillary bidentate C,N ligand in dichloromethane led to formation of complexes 1–6 as cationic species [Ir(η5:κ1-C5Me4CH2py)(C,N)]+, which were isolated as the hexafluorophosphate salts in good yields (45–60%). All complexes were obtained as the closed-tether species, whereby the pyridine moiety of the η5-bound cyclopentadienyl ligand in C5Me4CH2py is coordinatively attached to the iridium center in a κN manner, forming an additional chelate hereinafter referred to as “tether ring” or “tether”. While the η5-Cp ligand is firmly bound to the iridium in a η5 fashion, affording a half-sandwich structure, the κN-bound pyridine could be susceptible to dissociation from the metal center by nucleophilic attack on the iridium. Pyridine-bearing complexes and the subsequent pyridine–metal dissociation in this class of metallodrugs have been reported as a successful feature to afford controlled activation (generating a vacancy in the metal’s first coordination sphere) of the metal center in Ru(II)–arene(27) and Ir(III)–C5Me4R complexes.(13a) In our design, the otherwise leaving pyridine group is attached to the rest of the metal-based structure, tethered to the complex and forming an extra chelate. Provided that the pyridine dissociates from the metal, such a process would be reversible, perhaps allowing for control over the extent of the compound’s reactivity in the biological environment. X-ray crystal structure analysis (complexes 1, 2, 4, 5, and 6) aided to unequivocally assign the closed-tether ring structures.
    A nontether series analogous to 1 and a nontether series analogous to 2 (Chart 1) were synthesized in order to probe the biological effect of having the extra chelate Ir(η5:κ1-C5Me4CH2pyN) in our structure. These analogues were designed to represent complexes 1–6 if the Ir–N(tether) bond would be reactive in water or biological media, that is, to confirm the stability of the tether ring structure in the cell-based assays. Complexes bearing 2-phenylpyridine with formula [Ir(η5-C5Me5)(Phpy)Z]0/+ (Z = Cl, 1a; Z = py, 1b), [Ir(η5-C5Me4CH2Ph)(Phpy)Z]0/+ (C5Me4CH2Ph = ((2,3,4,5-tetramethylcyclopentadienyl)methyl)benzene, Z = Cl, 1c; Z = py, 1d), and 7,8-benzoquinoline with formula [Ir(η5-C5Me5)(Bzq)Z]0/+ (Z = Cl, 2a; Z = py, 2b), and [Ir(η5-C5Me4CH2Ph)(Bzq)Cl] (2c), were synthesized in good yields (59–99%) according to literature methods.(16b,28) Complexes 1a, 1c, 2a, and 2c were isolated as neutral, while cationic complexes 1b, 1d, and 2b were isolated as the hexafluorophosphate salts. Complexes 1a and 2a have been previously reported by Ling et al.(29) Complexes 1b, 1c, 1d, 2b, and 2c have not been reported before.
    All 13 complexes in this work were fully characterized by elemental analysis, 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy (Supporting Information (SI), Figures S1–S13), mass spectrometry, and complexes 1, 2, 4, 5, and 6 also by single crystal X-ray diffraction, as described in the Experimental Section of this manuscript. Synthesis and characterization of the substituted Cp ligands, and the corresponding Cp dimers or monomers are not included in this manuscript as they are already reported.(23,30)
    Complexes 1–6, 1a–1d, and 2a–2c exhibited good solubility in polar aprotic solvents such as dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), and chlorinated solvents such as chloroform (CHCl3) and dichloromethane (CH2Cl2). Complexes 1–6 were poorly soluble in aqueous solutions, thus impairing kinetic studies in water by means of 1H NMR spectroscopy. Nontoxic amounts of DMSO or DMF were used in the biological experiments to assist dissolution. The complexes were fully soluble at the maximum concentration used during the biological assays (SI, Figure S14 and Table S1).

    X-ray Crystal Structures

    Crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained from chloroform solutions at 298 K for [Ir(η5:κ1-C5Me4CH2py)(Phpy)]PF6 (1), [Ir(η5:κ1-C5Me4CH2py)(Bzq)]PF6 (2), [Ir(η5:κ1-C5Me4CH2py)(MePhpy)]PF6 (4), [Ir(η5:κ1-C5Me4CH2py)(ClPhq)]PF6 (5), and [Ir(η5:κ1-C5Me4CH2py)(dFPhpy)]PF6 (6). X-ray diffraction data corresponding to closed-tether complexes were collected for all complexes and are shown in Figure 1.
    Selected bond lengths and angles are shown in Table 1 and detailed crystallographic data in Table S2 of the Supporting Information. The complexes adopt the expected “piano-stool” geometry for half-sandwich iridium η5-bound to the substituted cyclopentadienyl ligand occupying three of the six pseudo-octahedral positions. The other three positions in the first coordination sphere are occupied by a bidentate chelating ligand and a pyridine group (pendant from the η5-bound cyclopentadienyl), forming a five-membered tether ring in the structure. Structures of closed-tether complexes 1 and 2 crystallized with four molecules, 5 with eight molecules, and 4 and 6 with two molecules in the unit cell and interstitial chloroform. Complex 1 adopts the two possible orientations for the bidentate asymmetric ligand Phpy, showing the N2 and C16 atoms bound to the iridium atom in a statistical proportion of 62% and 38%, respectively. Therefore, the crystal contains the two isomers arbitrarily placed in that distribution. The crystal structures of the five complexes show similar bond lengths and angles. In particular, the Ir–N1 distances for the five crystal structures are not significantly different from one another (<3σ) ranging from 2.086(6) to 2.099(6) Å. The Ir–centroid distances vary in the range 1.800–1.830 Å.
    Table 1. Selected Bond Lengths (Å) and Angles (deg) for Complexes [Ir(η5:κ1-C5Me4CH2py)(Phpy)]PF6 (1), [Ir(η5:κ1-C5Me4CH2py)(Bzq)]PF6 (2), [Ir(η5:κ1-C5Me4CH2py(MePhpy)]PF6 (4), [Ir(η5:κ1-C5Me4CH2py)(ClPhq)]PF6 (5), and [Ir(η5:κ1-C5Me4CH2py)(dFPhpy)]PF6 (6)a
    complex12456
    Ir–C12.111(7)2.144(5)2.127(7)2.147(7)2.116(5)
    Ir–C22.195(7)2.170(6)2.151(8)2.268(7)2.226(5)
    Ir–C32.210(7)2.196(5)2.201(7)2.238(7)2.236(5)
    Ir–C42.169(8)2.232(5)2.207(7)2.236(7)2.193(6)
    Ir–C52.202(8)2.205(6)2.224(7)2.130(8)2.170(7)
    Ir–centroid1.8051.8071.8001.8301.813

    Ir–C162.075(7)(A)/2.064(7)(B)2.077(6)2.053(8)2.049(7)2.051(6)

    C16–Ir–N277.7(3)78.8(2)78.3(3)77.6(3)78.3(2)

    N2–Ir–N192.1(2)(A)/93.4(2)(B)90.1(18)96.1(2)91.8(2)90.7(18)
    offset C6b0.348 (+)0.311 (+)0.298 (+)0.308 (+)0.317 (+)
    C1–centroid–Ir86.6986.5087.6087.1286.58
    σc5.083.330.961.783.69
    θ[Cp,py]d75.2177.3980.8474.2677.63
    a

    Schematic drawing including atom numbering of the core structure is presented for clarity.

    b

    Offset of C6 with respect to the plane formed by Ir-bound cyclopentadienyl (carbons C1–C5); (+) toward iridium.

    c

    Torsion angle of the planes containing C1, Ir, N1, and C7.

    d

    Angle between the plane of the cyclopentadienyl ring and the plane of the tethered pyridine.

    The five-member ring formed by the heteroditopic ligand η5-C5Me4CH2pyridine-κN might present some structural tension as previously observed by us for Ru(II) complexes bearing the ligand η6-2-aminobiphenyl-κN(22a) or η6-phenylacetate-κO.(22b) Strain release might have a crucial impact on the reactivity of the Ir–N1 bond when the complex is exposed to nucleophiles inside the cell. A useful parameter to assess the tether ring strain is the offset of C6 with regard to the plane that contains the η5-bound cyclopentadienyl (Figure 2). The C6 offset ranges from 0.298 to 0.348 Å toward the iridium atom in complexes 1, 2, 4, 5, and 6, while the rest of the four methyl groups on the cyclopentadienyl structure (C12–C15) show an offset away from the iridium center (0.019–0.282 Å; SI, Table S3). Likewise, comparison of the X-ray structure of complex 1 with the nontether structure 1a published by Li et al.(28) shows a pronounced offset of the five methyl groups on the Cp away from the iridium with respect to the plane that contains the η5-cyclopentadienyl (0.015–0.163 Å; SI, Table S3). An additional parameter that can help to understand the strain introduced in the structure by the tether ring is the angle between the iridium atom, the cyclopentadienyl centroid, and C1 (Figure 2). Expected to be approximately 90°, any deviation from that value represents a tilt on the cyclopentadienyl ligand with regard to the plane perpendicular to the Ir–centroid distance. We found that in the five crystal structures analyzed here such angle ranges from 86.50° to 87.60°, showing how the closure of the tether ring tilts the Cp by C1 toward the tethering nitrogen. Such tension in tether ring-bearing Ru(II)–arene complexes has been previously reported, and it has been successfully related to the dynamics of the activation of the metal–nitrogen bond.(22a,b) We also observed a pronounce difference in an important parameter when comparing 1 to 1a and to the analogous structure [Ir(η5-C5Me4C6H4C6H5)(Phpy)py]+.(13a) The Ir–centroid distance was shorter in our tether-bearing structure, 1: 1.805 Å, when compared to both 1a (CCDC 683546), 1.826 Å and [Ir(η5-C5Me4C6H4C6H5)(Phpy)py]+ (CCDC 956067), 1.838 Å, supporting the fact that the tether ring appears to result in an unusually short distance between the iridium(III) and the cyclopentadienyl ring, indicating a stronger (more stable) Ir−η5-Cp bond.

    Reactivity toward Dimethyl Sulfoxide

    Strong affinity of iridium(III) complexes to bind dimethyl sulfoxide is well-known, and such an interaction appears to show a clear preference for the small molecule to coordinate the iridium center in a κS fashion.(31) We chose DMSO as the model nucleophile to activate the Ir–N(py) bond in the tether ring in complexes 1–6, reaction that can be easily followed by 1H NMR and UV–vis. Importantly, DMSO is a common solvent used in cell studies to aid dissolution when the drug to be tested for biological activity is poorly soluble in water, as is the case of the complexes in this work.
    Reactivity of the Ir–N(py) tether ring bond in complexes 1–6 toward dimethyl sulfoxide was studied by 1H NMR spectroscopy in pure [D6]DMSO at 298 K. Analysis of the 1H NMR spectra proved to be reliable evidence for the open- versus closed-tether ring status in Ir(III) cyclopentadienyl complexes in solution. 1H NMR spectra of freshly prepared 6–7 mM solutions for each complex were recorded in situ after sample preparation (t0 ≤ 5 min). The DMSO coordination to the iridium center was complete for all the complexes in less than 14 h and remained unchanged up to 24 h. No additional side products were observed during this time. The time dependence of the 1H NMR spectra is illustrated for complex 1 in SI, Figure S15. Initially, the 1H NMR spectra displayed one major set of peaks at high field attributable to the closed-tether species: four singlets at 1.4–2.5 ppm assignable to the four methyl groups in the Cp ligand, and a minor set of peaks assignable to the open-tether species, four singlets in the narrower range 1.6–1.8 ppm. The second set of peaks increased over time, while the first set disappeared, indicating total conversion from 1 to 1-dmso of formula [Ir(η5-C5Me4CH2py)(Phpy)(DMSO)]+.
    UV–visible spectroscopy was then used to determine the kinetic parameters. UV–vis data of 0.1 mM solutions were recorded over time (t0 ≤ 1 min) until no further changes were observed. The time dependence of the UV–vis absorption spectra of the dimethyl sulfoxide solution of complexes 1–6 are shown in SI, Figure S16. In every case, the substitution reaction followed pseudo first-order kinetics (insets in SI, Figure S16), corresponding to the rate constants kDMSO listed in Table 2, ranging from 34.29 for the slowest 5 to 216.98 × 10–6 s–1 for the fastest 2.
    Table 2. Rate Constants and Half-Times from DMSO Coordination (DMSO-Driven Tether-Opening Process) of Tether Complexes 1–6 and Nontethered Complexes 1a, 1b, 1c, 2a, and 2b at 298 K as Determined by UV–Visible Spectroscopy
    complexCpX,Y ligandZ ligandk x 10–6 [s–1]t1/2 [min]
    1C5Me4CH2pyPhpy 70.28 ± 4.31165.00 ± 10
    2C5Me4CH2pyBzq 216.98 ± 3.3253.24 ± 0.81
    3C5Me4CH2pyPhq 63.18 ± 2.95183.21 ± 8.37
    4C5Me4CH2pyMePhpy 110.57 ± 8.24158.67 ± 17.77
    5C5Me4CH2pyClPhq 34.29 ± 0.17336.87 ± 1.63
    6C5Me4CH2pydFPhpy 43.72 ± 3.85264.26 ± 22.30
         
    1aC5Me5PhpyCl10.27 ± 1.841124.85 ± 208.27
    1bC5Me5Phpypy3.06 ± 0.113771.76 ± 135.74
    1cC5Me4CH2PhPhpyCl7.09 ± 0.521630.55 ± 119.13
         
    2aC5Me5BzqCl8.21 ± 0.161405.76 ± 27.89
    2bC5Me5Bzqpy2.93 ± 0.763936.97 ± 1087.92
    To understand the effect of the tether ring structural constrain on the Ir–N(py) reactivity of this class of compound, interaction with DMSO was investigated for nontethered analogues of 1: complexes 1a, 1b, and 1c (SI, Figure S17). All complexes convert to the Ir–DMSO adduct [Ir(η5-C5Me4R)(Phpy)(DMSO)]+ (R = Me for 1a and 1b, and CH2Ph for 1c) over time. The different species were characterized by 1H NMR, while UV–vis spectra allowed for determination of the kinetic constants (Table 2). The results show that nontethered analogues of 1 are less reactive toward DMSO coordination than tethered complexes 1–6. Reaction of complex 1a is 7× slower (10.27 ± 1.84 × 10–6 s–1), 1b is 23× slower (3.06 ± 0.11 × 10–6 s–1), and 1c is 10× slower (7.09 ± 0.52 × 10–6 s–1) than 1 (70.28 ± 4.31 × 10–6 s–1). In the case of analogues of complex 2 (SI, Figure S17), for which kDMSO is determined as 216.98 ± 3.32 × 10–6 s–1, a similar yet more pronounced tendency is observed: 2a is 26× slower (8.21 ± 0.16 × 10–6 s–1), while 2b is 74× slower (2.93 ± 0.76 × 10–6 s–1).
    Faster hydrolysis rate for metal–Cl in comparison to metal–pyridine-κN has been previously reported for iridium(III) and also for other metal complexes such as Ru(II)(13a,27,32) and Rh(III),(33) indicating that chlorido is a better leaving group in aqueous solution than the pyridine ligand. This explains the trend observed for the rate constants in the substitution reactions of nontethered complexes 1a–1c, kDMSO(1a) ∼ kDMSO(1c) > kDMSO(1b), and 2a and 2b, kDMSO(2a) > kDMSO(2b). Accordingly, we would have expected kDMSO(1) and kDMSO(2) to have the slowest rate in their respective series because the leaving group is a pyridine-κN forming a chelate. Surprisingly, the opposite is observed, and the substitution reactions by DMSO in complexes 1–6 is significantly faster (up to 74-fold) than in complexes 1a–1c, and 2a and 2b (Table 2 and SI, Figure S18). We attribute this rapid reaction with the strong nucleophile DMSO to the structural constraint in the five-membered tether ring, as discussed above regarding their X-ray structures (Figure 2). It is curious to note that complex 2, the most biologically potent of the series (vide infra), shows the fastest kDMSO (216.98 × 10–6 s–1) of complexes 1–6.
    Dimethyl sulfoxide is a common solvent to aid dissolution during biological assays of metal complexes. We thus investigated the reactivity of our complexes when, upon dissolution in DMSO and formation of the Ir–DMSO adduct, they were diluted into water at ca. pH 7. Strikingly, once the Ir-DMSO adduct is redissolved in water, the tether ring forms again, likely via the aqua-adduct intermediate, and the complex largely precipitates as a yellow powder due to the low solubility in water of the closed-tether compound (complex 1, as an example in SI, Figure S19). Despite the fast reactivity of the metal center in pure DMSO, the stability of the η5:κ1-tether ring-bearing organometallic moiety appears to play therefore a crucial role in aqueous solution, perhaps preserving the cationic doubly chelated structure and protecting the iridium(III) center from nucleophilic attack in aqueous (biological) media.

    Cytotoxicity/Antiproliferative Activity of Ir(III) Compounds against Cancer Cells

    The activity of the Ir(III) complexes on cell viability was evaluated against MCF7 human breast cancer cells. Our assay to determine the IC50 values includes both cytotoxicity (cell death) and antiproliferative effects (inhibition of growth). Our results reveal that all Ir(III) compounds resulted in a decrease of the global population of MCF7 cells compared to control at the concentrations used (Figure 3 and Table 3) at least as efficiently as cisplatin, complexes 1–6 being significantly more active: highly potent, well below the micromolar range. The IC50 values for 2, 3, and 4 were 0.06 ± 0.02, 0.05 ± 0.01, and 0.05 ± 0.01 μM, respectively, followed by 1, 5, and 6, with IC50 values of 0.11 ± 0.03, 0.22 ± 0.00, and 0.19 ± 0.02 μM, respectively. The nontethered analogues 1a–d and 2a–c were also evaluated. Their potency, with IC50 values ranging from 14.90 ± 3.39 μM (2a) to 1.85 ± 1.13 μM (1d), was similar to that of cisplatin (9.7 ± 1.9 μM). All were, however, less active than the tether ring-bearing complexes.
    Table 3. Inhibitory Effects of Ir(III) Complexes on the Growth of MCF7 and MRC-5 Cells in Vitroa
     IC50b (μM) ± SD 
    compdMCF7MRC-5IC50 (MRC-5)/IC50 (MCF7)c
    10.11 ± 0.031.16 ± 0.3010.55
         
    1a12.37 ± 1.8520.77 ± 4.621.68
    1b9.30 ± 1.0915.20 ± 0.591.63
    1c3.34 ± 0.7016.63 ± 0.004.98
    1d1.85 ± 1.1316.18 ± 0.008.75
         
    20.06 ± 0.021.33 ± 0.0022.17
         
    2a14.90 ± 3.3935.74 ± 5.992.40
    2b5.05 ± 0.3519.82 ± 0.003.92
    2c4.42 ± 1.195.54 ± 0.001.25
         
    30.05 ± 0.011.90 ± 0.4338.00
    40.05 ± 0.014.59 ± 1.7191.80
    50.22 ± 0.001.52 ± 0.176.91
    60.19 ± 0.025.50 ± 0.0028.95
    a

    The drug treatment period was 24 h (+72 h cell recovery).

    b

    IC50 is defined as the concentration of drug required to inhibit cell population growth by 50% compared to control, as a result of varying degrees of drug cytotoxicity and antiproliferative activity. CDDP was used as positive control (IC50 = 9.7 ± 1.9 μM for MCF7 and 15.2 ± 5.7 μM for MRC-5 cells). Experiments were performed in triplicate, and data are displayed as an average of at least two independent experiments. All values were compared to the untreated controls and to one another for statistical significance calculations: p < 0.001.

    c

    Ratio IC50 (MRC-5)/IC50 (MCF7) represent the IC50 values in MRC-5 cells divided by IC50 values in MCF7 cells for each Ir(III) compound.

    We were not expecting the IC50 data to show such an increased potency by introducing a tether ring in the Ir(III) structure. Our previous results regarding Ru(II)–arene complexes presenting the same type of tethered structure had shown a similar behavior in water,(22a,b) where the complexes were extraordinarily stable at neutral pH and accordingly had presented no effect in cell viability. Complexes 1–6 appear as robust in water at neutral pH, yet conversely to ruthenium(II) tethers, our data suggest that introduction of the tethering η5-C5Me4CH2py-κN ligand confers high anticancer potency to the Ir(III) half-sandwich complexes.
    In the past decade, a number of studies have reported Ir(III)-cyclopentadienyl complexes with typical half-sandwich structure as potent as clinically used drug cisplatin in a range of cancer cells. Sadler reported the optimization of the C5Me4R-derivative, finding that an extended hydrophobic face on the derivative-Cp ligand increases cytotoxicity in comparison to C5Me5-Ir(III) (ca. 10- to 100-fold),(15) while substituting N,N-ancillary ligands for their isoelectronic C,N-analogous would also afford a significant increase in the cytotoxic potency.(16,34) Further exploration of the effect on the XY bidentate ligand in the general structure [Ir(η5-C5Me5)(XY)Cl] has been a subject of much research,(5a,13e,19,35) reporting complexes as active as cisplatin in a number of cancer cell lines. The next leap in cytotoxicity with regard to SAR came from varying the monodentate ligand, also known as the “leaving group”. The chemical reactivity of the bond between this ligand and the metal center can have a dramatic influence on the cytotoxicity of the compound. In particular, the substitution of the Cl monodentate ligand by a pyridine-κN group, affording the complex [Ir(η5-C5Me4C6H4C6H5)(Phpy)(py)]PF6 resulted in an enhanced cytotoxic potency, with an IC50 value of 0.12 μM toward A2780 cells,(13a) producing the most potent C5Me5-derivative Ir(III) complex reported to date.
    Our IC50 results of nontether complexes appear to be consistent with the reported SAR regarding monodentate ligand (Z) optimization in complexes of formula [Ir(η5-C5Me4R)(XY)(Z)]n+. For example, comparison of anticancer potency of 1b vs 1a, 1d vs 1c, and 2b vs 2a appears to show that pyridine-bearing complexes are more active than the chlorido counterparts. This has been previously related to excess reactivity of the latter, that is, bearing rapidly hydrolyzing Ir–Z bonds results in lower potency, perhaps due to a short activation time less compatible with reaching the biological target site.(13a)
    The latter concept regarding the link between anticancer potency and lack of hydrolysis of the Ir(III)–N(py) bond in aqueous solution appears to apply to our new family of tether ring-bearing complexes 1–6. Strikingly active, all six complexes show high potency toward MCF7 human cancer cells, considerably higher than CDDP (0.05–0.22 vs 9.7 μM), and also significantly higher than the nontether analogues (1.85–14.90 μM), even those bearing a κN-bound pyridine as monodentate ligand. Importantly, such different anticancer potency between tether and nontether analogues represents an indirect proof that the tether ring remains stable in the biological media. We argue that the double chelate results in a closed tether Ir(III) structure which allows for effective transport to the target in the nucleophile-rich intracellular environment.
    Additional IC50 determinations using N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) as a vehicle to aid dissolution of complexes 1–6 were also carried out. DMF behaves in many ways like DMSO; it is a very polar solvent that dissolves most organic and inorganics salts, but it is not significantly nucleophilic for our studies and does not coordinate to our closed tether complexes 1–6 (see SI, Figure S20 showing the stability of ca. 7 mM complex 1 as an example in [D7]DMF by 1H NMR). Cell viability screening results in MCF7 are in agreement with the IC50 values obtained with DMSO as a vehicle for our cell viability tests, supporting the observation that a possible DMSO-mediated tether ring opening would have no effect in the cell viability tests in aqueous solution, further supporting the stability of complexes 1–6 in aqueous biological media. Determination of IC50 values in ovarian cancer cell line A2780 using both DMSO and DMF as vehicles also corroborated this observation. Data of these experiments are included in the Supporting Information (SI, Table S4).
    To explore the ubiquitous potency of our new family of iridium-tether complexes, we also tested complexes 1–6 toward additional human cancer cells from tissues of different origin: colon tumor cell line HCT116, breast cancer cell line MDA-MB-231, and pancreatic cancer cell lines MIA PaCa-2 and PANC-1 (SI, Table S5). All tether complexes present high potency, with IC50 values in the submicromolar range, about 2 orders of magnitude lower than those of cisplatin.
    Finally, we also assayed healthy-cell toxicity of Ir(III) complexes on MRC-5, a nontumorigenic human lung fibroblast cell type, to investigate cancer cell selectivity, by the MTS assay (Table 3 and SI, Figure S21). Despite presenting high toxicity in noncancerous cells, all Ir(III) compounds showed higher IC50 values in MRC-5 cells compared to MCF7 cells. Remarkably, while nontether complexes 1a–1d, and 2a–2c show a IC50 (MRC-5)/IC50 (MCF7) toxicity ratio in the range 1.25–8.75, the same ratio for 1–6 spans 2 orders of magnitude (up to 91.80 for 4), showing that the tether complexes appear to exhibit some selectivity toward cancer cells.

    Induction of Intracellular Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS) by Ir(III) Compounds in MCF7 Cells

    It is increasingly recognized that generation of excessive levels of ROS by different anticancer drugs can lead to oxidative stress and activation of cell death processes in a variety of organisms.(12,36) Motivated by the fact that the anticancer activity of Ir(III)-cyclopentadienyl complexes can be linked to the increase of ROS production by targeting the redox balance in tumor cells,(2b,13a−c,37) we investigated intracellular ROS level alteration in MCF7 cells. We used the cell-permeable nonfluorescent probe DCFH-DA, which internalizes, hydrolyses, and converts into highly fluorescent DCF upon oxidation by various reactive oxygen species. Our assay indicates generalized oxidative stress rather than an accurate measure of specific reactive oxygen or nitrogen species. As it can be seen in Figure 4A, none of the nontethered iridium complexes 1a–1d induced a significant level of total ROS, while compound 1 triggered ROS production at the higher concentration used (1 μM). Results obtained for nontethered complexes 2a–2c (Figure 4B) are similar to those of complexes 1a–1d, yet compound 2, which is significantly more active than 1, induced high sustained levels of total ROS at all concentrations tested. Figure 4C shows that compounds 3–6 all produced similar ROS accumulation than that observed for 2.
    Our results correlate well with the anticancer potency of the Ir(III) complexes studied in this work as all tethered compounds 1–6 showed greater cytotoxicity and induction of total ROS levels, whereas the nontethered iridium complexes presented low anticancer activity and did not induce ROS generation at the highest concentration tested. Following these results, we next investigated whether one of the major antioxidant systems in cells, such as the thioredoxin reductase system, would be implicated in iridium(III)-driven cell death.

    Inhibition of TrxR Activity by Ir(III) Complexes in Vitro and in MCF7 Cells

    The Trx system comprises the small redox protein thioredoxin (Trx), selenocysteine-containing thioredoxin reductase (TrxR) and NADPH. It is a key antioxidant system in mammalian cells and plays important roles in maintaining the redox intracellular balance controlling ROS production.(38) Recent studies have indicated that TrxR can be strongly inhibited by metal-based anticancer candidates, particularly of gold and iridium, in experiments carried out in a test tube, i.e., outside the cell.(20,39) Importantly, TrxR is a ROS-scavenging enzyme, highly expressed in cancer cells, protecting them from death.(40)
    We evaluated the inhibitory effect of the Ir(III) complexes on the enzymatic activity of TrxR (SI, Table S6 and Figure S22). Among all the tethered compounds, 1, 2, and 3 were effective inhibitors of TrxR activity, exhibiting EC50 values of 0.31, 2.5, and 6.1 μM, respectively. Under the same experimental conditions, compound 5 was less effective, with EC50 value equal to 38.8 μM, while compounds 4 and 6 were devoid of activity against the enzyme at concentrations up to 50 μM. Nontethered complexes bearing a chlorido ligand cause no alterations in TrxR activity, and strong inhibition by 1b and moderate inhibitory effect for 2b was observed (EC50 values of 0.032 and 4.2 μM, respectively), intriguingly, the two complexes bearing a pyridine-κN as a monodentate leaving group.
    We have previously observed divergence between the TrxR inhibition results in the test tube and in cell lysates for a family of cytotoxic Au(III)–bisthiosemicarbazone complexes.(41) We then determined the TrxR activity in cell lysates of MCF7 cells after treatment with the iridium(III) compounds in order to relate such interaction to anticancer activity (SI, Table S6). Complex 2 showed the most effective TrxR inhibition, which accounted for a modest 28%. The data suggested that while most of the complexes reported here appear to inhibit the selenoenzyme in buffer solution in the low micromolar and submicromolar range, they appear not to be strong inhibitors of the enzyme upon cell internalization.

    Induction of Mitochondrial Dysfunction by Ir(III) Compounds in MCF7 Cells

    Mitochondria are the main producers of ROS in the cell, and mitochondrial damage may markedly increase intracellular ROS levels.(42) Loss of the mitochondrial membrane potential (ΔΨm) is an important indicator of mitochondrial dysfunction, a universal event that occurs in RCD in cancer cells.(43) A number of studies have related iridium(III) complexes-driven cell death to ΔΨm disruption.(13e,44) We studied the impact of the Ir(III)compounds on mitochondrial membrane integrity in MCF7 cells using flow cytometry analysis. MCF7 cells were exposed to 0.25 μM of the iridium complexes and the changes in ΔΨm were detected by JC-10 staining. We included cells treated with carbonyl cyanide m-chlorophenyl hydrazone (CCCP) as positive control, and untreated cells as negative control. As shown in Figure 5 (see also SI, Table S7 and Figure S23), after exposition of MCF7 cells to equimolar quantities of Ir(III) complexes, the fluorescence emission of JC-10 changed at different levels. Our results show that all nontethered complexes 1a–1d and 2a–2c presented no changes in the ΔΨm compared to untreated control cells. In contrast, all tether compounds 1–6 induce depolarization of the mitochondrial membrane that follow the trend of the positive control CCCP, albeit complexes 5 and 6 did not show a significant effect. Compounds 1 and 4 induced similar changes on the mitochondria membrane polarization to the positive control CCCP (ratios F4/F2 of 0.20 ± 0.01 and 0.17 ± 0.01, respectively, versus 0.18 ± 0.02 for the control), whereas 2 and 3 showed the strongest effect in the ΔΨm in the series (F4/F2 ratios of 0.32 ± 0.01 and 0.33 ± 0.02, respectively).
    Our results show that complexes 1–6 have an impact in ΔΨm in contrast to the nontethered compounds 1a–1d and 2a–2c at the concentration tested (0.25 μM), implying that this effect is most significant for the observed differences in anticancer potency exhibited by tether versus the nontether series. We have recently reported the localization of complex 1 in cryopreserved MCF7 cells with nanometric resolution by using a combination of 3D synchrotron-based techniques; cryo soft X-ray tomography (cryo-SXT) and cryo hard X-ray fluorescence (cryo-XRF). We have shown unambiguously the exclusive localization of complex 1 in the mitochondria of cryopreserved MCF7 cells,(26) without mechanical manipulation, staining, or labeling of the samples. We argue here that complexes 1–6, bearing hydrophobic ligands, behave as lipophilic cations, and as such, they are attracted by the negative membrane potential of the mitochondrial inner membrane,(6d) which is even more negative in some tumors.(9) It is reasonable to assume that once the complexes cross the cellular outer membrane against their concentration gradient, they will preferentially and efficiently accumulate in the inward side of the inner mitochondrial membrane.

    Cellular Accumulation of Ir(III) Complexes in MCF7 Cells

    Considering our previous work reporting unequivocal results for exclusive mitochondria targeting of complex 1,(26) and tentatively assuming a similar behavior for complexes 1–6, we tested whether the high potency of the tethered-Ir(III) complexes correlates with overall intracellular accumulation of the compounds. For that, total cellular internalization of iridium (net uptake between influx and efflux) into MCF7 cells were determined by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). First, we used two different concentrations for 24 h cell exposure: 0.005 μM, which is 1/10 IC50 of the most active compounds (3 and 4), and 0.25 μM, which is 5× IC50 of 3 and 4 and approximately the IC50 of the least actively tether-Ir(III) compound 5. All iridium(III) complexes 1–6 were accumulated inside the cell (Table 4) without significant differences among them for the two conditions assayed and extraordinarily efficient even at very low drug exposure.
    Table 4. Cellular Accumulation of Ir(III) Complexes (as ng Ir/106 Cells) in MCF7 Breast Cancer Cells
     internalization (ng Ir/106 cells)
    compd0.005 μMa0.25 μMa1 μMb
    10.33 ± 0.1229.7 ± 3.7100.2 ± 16.0
    1andnd14.5 ± 3.0
    1bndnd12.4 ± 2.5
    1cndnd9.3 ± 1.8
    1dndnd17.0 ± 1.2
    20.55 ± 0.0755.6 ± 8.0201.7 ± 22.4
    30.37 ± 0.0571.7 ± 10.3nd
    40.44 ± 0.0640.1 ± 3.5nd
    50.42 ± 0.0554.2 ± 6.2nd
    60.65 ± 0.0464.3 ± 4.6nd
    a

    Drug-treatment period was 24 h of exposure to 0.005 or 0.25 μM of Ir(III) tether complexes 1–6.

    b

    Cells were treated with 1 μM of Ir(III) compounds 1, 1a–1d, and 2 for 8 h. Cellular number was determined by counting on a hemocytometer prior to digestion. Iridium content was normalized to 106 cells per sample. Each value represents the mean ± CI. All values were compared to the untreated controls; p < 0.001. nd, not determined.

    Most importantly, we investigated the effect of the tether ring on iridium internalization in order to relate this feature to their potent cytotoxicity. We tested tether and nontether analogues: 1, 1a, 1b, 1c, and 1d, and 2. In the cell viability assays, the IC50 values obtained for these complexes varied from nanomolar to micromolar concentrations; therefore, to be able to use a high equimolar concentration without compromising cell viability, cells were treated with 1 μM of 1, 1a, 1b, 1c, 1d, and 2 for 8 h. Table 4 shows that compounds 1a, 1b, 1c, and 1d displayed similar low levels of iridium accumulation (14.5 ± 3.0, 12.4 ± 2.5, 9.3 ± 1.8, and 17.0 ± 1.2 ng Ir/106 cells for 1a, 1b, 1c, and 1d, respectively), whereas the cellular uptake of 1 was increased up to 10-fold when compared to them (100.2 ± 16.0 ng Ir/106 cells). Strikingly, complex 2 showed extraordinary Ir accumulation, the highest of all complexes tested (201.7 ± 22.4 ng Ir/106 cells). These results show that the degree of uptake of all Ir(III) complexes correlates significantly with the IC50 data. Compounds 1a, 1b, 1c, and 1d were the least potent and displayed the lowest cellular accumulation, whereas 2 presents the highest potency against MCF7 cells and the highest uptake efficiency.

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    It has been previously reported that the derivatized C5Me4R ring and the different chelating XY ligands play an important role in the anticancer activity of a number of Ir(III)–Cp complexes.(15,45) Importantly, the presence of a strongly bound pyridine ligand significantly improves the anticancer potency of this class of drug candidates.(13a) Here we report the synthesis and characterization of a series of iridium(III) cyclopentadienyl complexes 1–6 with typical half-sandwich structure. In comparison to the already reported Ir(III)–Cp metallodrugs, complexes 1–6 of general formula [Ir(η5:κ1-C5Me4CH2py)(C,N)]PF6, include a very particular feature in their structure, an additional chelate ring formed by coordinative binding of a pyridine-κN, which is tethered to the η5-bound cyclopentadienyl ring (Chart 1). We report the first five crystal structures of Ir(III) complexes bearing the heteroditopic ligand η5-C5Me4CH2pyridine-κN and substituted C,N bidentate chelating ligands, highlighting the structural robustness of our doubly chelated Ir-tether complexes. The tether ring feature appears to confer extraordinary anticancer potency toward MCF7 cancer cells to this new class of metallodrugs, up to 2 orders of magnitude more active than clinically used anticancer drug cisplatin. Complexes 1–6 are equally potent in additional cancer cells, such as A2780, HCT116, MDA-MB-231, MIA PaCa-2, and PANC-1. For comparison purposes, we have synthesized a number of nontethered analogues, complexes 1a–1d and 2a–2c of general formula [Ir(η5-C5Me4R)(Phpy/Bzq)Z]0/+ (Chart 1), which helped to rationalize the observed high activity of the tether-bearing complexes. Such a comparison was also decisive as an indirect proof of tether ring stability in biological media. We have shown that the tether complexes are readily reactive toward DMSO, yet they are extraordinarily stable in water. We have tried to relate the unexpected leap in potency to total ROS production and mitochondria depolarization. In addition, these complexes clearly distinguish themselves from their nontether counterparts in their internalization and target-reaching capabilities. They appear to internalize readily even at very low drug concentrations and target efficiently and exclusively the cell mitochondria in MCF7 cells without deviating from their intracellular goal.
    We argue that the tether ring in complexes 1–6, and the extra stabilization that it provides the complexes with, shelters the metal center toward nucleophilic attack, protecting the Ir(III) closed-tether structure, a lipophilic cation that, attracted by the negative potential of the mitochondrial inner membrane, targets the cancer cell mitochondria in a highly efficient manner. The tether ring structural feature in this new class of Ir-tether anticancer agents results in an extraordinary leap in anticancer potency, probably related to a highly efficient internalization followed by a clear targeting of the cell mitochondria, its depolarization and the subsequent oxidative stress.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Materials

    IrCl3·3H2O was acquired from Johnson Matthey. 2-(2,4-Difluorophenyl)pyridine, 2-(p-tolyl)pyridine, 4-chloro-2-phenylquinoline, 2.5 M n-buthylithium (n-BuLi), silver nitrate (AgNO3), sodium acetate (NaOAc), formic acid (FA), ammonium hexafluorophosphate (NH4PF6), and 1.0 M benzylmagnesium bromide were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. 2-Picoline, 2,3,4,5-tetramethylcyclopentenone, and 1,2,3,4-pentamethylcyclopentadiene were acquired from Alfa Aesar. 1-Phenylisoquinoline was purchased from FluoroChem. 2-Phenylpyridine, 7,8-benzoquinoline, diisopropylamine (DIPA), dry tetrahydrofuran (THF), dichloromethane (DCM), dimethylformamide (DMF), and dichloroethane (DCE) were acquired from Acros Organics, dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) from VWR International, ethanol and Celite from Sharlau, dry methanol from Alfa Aesar, and diethyl ether from Fisher Scientific. For NMR spectroscopy, the solvents used were CDCl3 and [D6]DMSO from VWR International, and [D7]DMF from abcr GmbH.

    Experimental Details

    Reactions were carried out in oven-dried glassware under inert atmosphere (argon or nitrogen) using standard vacuum line techniques. Room or ambient temperature refers to 20–25 °C. Reactions involving heating were performed using blocks and a contact thermocouple. Under reduced pressure refers to the use of a Büchi Rotavapor R-200/210 with a Büchi V-491 heating bath and a Büchii V-800/850 vacuum controller. The rotary evaporator condenser is fitted to Huber Minichiller 280 recirculating cooler filled with ethylene glycol and set to −5 °C.
    All tested compounds, including cisplatin (Sigma-Aldrich, ≥99.9%), possess a purity of at least ≥95%, as determined by combustion analysis.

    [Ir(η5:κ1-C5Me4CH2py)(Phpy)]PF6 (1)

    A solution of [Ir(η5:κ1-C5Me4CH2py)Cl2](40.0 mg, 0.084 mmol, 1.0 equiv) and AgNO3 (28.5 mg, 0.168 mmol, 2.0 equiv) in deionized water (13.4 mL) was stirred at ambient temperature overnight. The resulting precipitate (AgCl) was removed by filtration over Celite, washed through with deionized water, and the filtrate was concentrated in vacuo until dryness. The desired aqua complex was used in the next step without further purification. It was dissolved in anhydrous dichloromethane (28.2 mL), and 2-phenylpyridine (27.1 μL, 0.019 mmol, 2.3 equiv) and NaOAc (31.2 mg, 0.380 mmol, 4.5 equiv) were added to the solution. The reaction mixture was heated under reflux in an Ar atmosphere for 24 h. The resulting solution was filtered over Celite, washed through with dichloromethane, and concentrated in vacuo until dryness. The solid was washed with diethyl ether, redissolved in methanol, and an excess of NH4PF6 (68.5 mg, 0.42 mmol, 5.0 equiv) was added. The solution was left to stand in the freezer (−20 °C) overnight, and the resulting product was collected by filtration, washed with diethyl ether, and dried under vacuum. The title compound was obtained as brown-orange powder (42.4 mg, 71%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 8.87 (d, J = 5.3 Hz, 1H), 8.02 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 1H), 7.91–7.85 (m, 2H), 7.79 (dd, J = 5.7, 3.1 Hz, 1H), 7.65 (td, J = 7.8, 1.6 Hz, 1H), 7.38–7.31 (m, 2H), 7.24 (dd, J = 5.7, 3.2 Hz, 2H), 6.80 (t, J = 6.1 Hz, 1H), 6.56 (dd, J = 5.8, 1.2 Hz, 1H), 4.25 (d, J = 18.9 Hz, 1H), 3.98 (d, J = 19.0 Hz, 1H), 2.39 (s, 3H), 1.97 (s, 3H), 1.60 (s, 3H), 1.46 (s, 3H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 179.71 (C), 166.78 (C), 162.99 (C), 152.03 (CH), 149.08 (CH), 143.85 (C), 139.09 (CH), 138.48 (CH), 134.82 (CH), 131.59 (CH), 125.36 (CH), 125.16 (CH), 124.90 (CH), 124.22 (CH), 124.18 (CH), 120.06 (CH), 103.11 (C), 91.91 (C), 91.81 (C), 91.44 (C), 71.52 (C), 32.47 (CH2), 9.25 (CH3), 9.23 (CH3), 8.39 (CH3), 8.08 (CH3). Elemental Analysis calculated for C26H26F6N2PIr (703.68): C, 44.38; H, 3.72; N, 3.98. Found C, 44.45; H, 3.82; N, 3.99. MS (ESI) m/z calculated for C26H26N2Ir [M]+ 559.2; found 559.3. Suitable crystals for X-ray diffraction were obtained by crystallization from chloroform/methanol at 298 K.

    [Ir(η5-C5Me5)(Phpy)Cl] (1a)

    A solution of [Ir(η5-C5Me5)Cl2]2 (60.0 mg, 0.076 mmol, 1.0 equiv), 2-phenylpyridine (21.6 μL, 0.152 mmol, 2.0 equiv), and NaOAc (24.9 mg, 0.304 mmol, 4.0 equiv) in dichloromethane (3.3 × 10–3 M) was heated under reflux in a N2 atmosphere for 24 h. The solution was filtered over Celite, washed through with dichloromethane, and concentrated in vacuo until dryness. The solid was washed with diethyl ether and dried under vacuum. The title compound was obtained as a bright-orange solid (85.5 mg, 99%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 8.70 (dd, J = 5.7, 0.6 Hz, 1H), 7.82 (d, J = 7.7 Hz, 2H), 7.70–7.63 (m, 2H), 7.21 (td, J = 7.4, 1.3 Hz, 1H), 7.10–7.01 (m, 2H), 1.68 (s, 15H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 167.56 (C), 163.51 (C), 151.49 (CH), 144.22 (C), 137.08 (CH), 135.97 (CH), 131.17 (CH), 123.99 (CH), 122.38 (CH), 122.21 (CH), 119.02 (CH), 88.67 (5 × Q), 9.06 (5 × CH3). Elemental Analysis calculated for C21H23ClNIr (517.10): C 48.78, H 4.48, N 2.71; found C 48.80, H 4.55, N 2.67. MS (ESI): m/z calculated for C21H23NIr [M]+ 482.2; found 482.3.

    [Ir(η5-C5Me5)(Phpy)(py)]PF6 (1b)

    A solution of 1a (40.0 mg, 0.05 mmol, 1.0 equiv) and AgNO3 (8.5 mg, 0.05 mmol, 1.0 equiv) in dry methanol (0.01 M) was left to stir overnight at ambient temperature. The precipitate (AgCl) was removed by filtration through a syringe filter, and excess pyridine (40 μL, 0.5 mmol, 10.0 equiv) was added to the filtrate. The reaction mixture was stirred overnight at ambient temperature. The volume was slowly reduced to less than half on a rotatory evaporator before NH4PF6 (40.8 mg, 0.25 mmol, 5.0 equiv) was added. The solution was left to stand in the freezer (−20 °C) overnight, and the corresponding product was collected by filtration and washed with diethyl ether and dried under vacuum. The title compound was obtained as an orange solid (30.3 mg, 86%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 9.11 (d, J = 5.7 Hz, 1H), 8.48–8.44 (m, 2H), 7.88 (dd, J = 7.5, 0.8 Hz, 1H), 7.83–7.74 (m, 2H), 7.65–7.57 (m, 3H), 7.37 (td, J = 7.4, 1.3 Hz, 1H), 7.31–7.26 (m, 2H), 7.18 (td, J = 7.6, 1.1 Hz, 1H), 1.60 (s, 15H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 160.98 (C), 153.47 (2 × CH), 152.44 (C), 145.59 (C), 139.13 (CH), 138.57 (CH), 134.88 (CH), 132.06 (CH), 127.19 (CH), 125.77 (CH), 125.59 (CH), 124.46 (CH), 124.04 (CH), 119.24 (CH), 90.56 (5 × C), 8.65 (5 × CH3). Elemental Analysis calculated for C26H28F6N2PIr (705.70): C 44.25, H 4.00, N 3.97; found C 43.99, H 4.00, N 4.03. MS (ESI): m/z calculated for C21H23NIr [M]+ 482.2; found 482.2.

    [Ir(η5-C5Me4CH2Ph)(Phpy)(Cl)] (1c)

    Following the procedure to synthesize complex 1a, complex 1c was prepared using the [Ir(η5-C5Me4CH2Ph)Cl2]2 dimer (35.0 mg, 0.04 mmol, 1.0 equiv), 2-phenylpyridine (11.4 μL, 0.08 mmol, 2.0 equiv) as the bidentate chelating ligand, and NaOAc (13.12 mg, 0.16 mmol, 4.0 equiv) as a weak base.     [Ir(η5:κ1-C5Me4CH2py)Ir(Bzq)]PF6 (2)

    [Ir(η5:κ1-C5Me4CH2py)(MePhpy)]PF6 (4)

    [Ir(η5:κ1-C5Me4CH2py)(dFPhpy)]PF6 (6)

    Following the procedure to synthesize complex 1, complex 6 was prepared using 2-(2,4-difluorophenyl)pyridine, dFPhpy (29.0 μL, 0.190 mmol, 2.3 equiv), as bidentate chelating ligand. Suitable crystals for X-ray diffraction were obtained by crystallization from chloroform/methanol at 298 K.

    Methods and Instrumentation

    Single Crystal X-ray Diffraction

    Suitable crystals for 1, 2, 4, 5, and 6 were coated with mineral oil mounted on Mitegen MicroMounts. The samples were measured at 150 K in a Bruker D8 KAPPA APEX II diffractometer with CCD area detector, equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The substantial redundancy in data allowed empirical absorption corrections (SADABS) to be applied using multiple measurements of symmetry-equivalent reflections. Raw intensity data frames were integrated with the SAINT program, which also applied corrections for Lorentz and polarization effects. The Bruker SHELXTL software package was used for space group determination, structure solution, and refinement. The space group determination was based on a check of the Laue symmetry, and systematic absences were confirmed using the structure solution. The structures were solved by direct methods (SHELXL-2014/7), completed with different Fourier syntheses, and refined with full-matrix least-squares using SHELXS minimizing ω(Fo2 – Fc2)2. Weighted R factors (Rw) and goodness of fit (S) are based on F2; conventional R factors (R) are based on F. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Hydrogen atom positions were geometrically calculated and allowed to ride on their parent carbon or nitrogen atoms with fixed isotropic U. All scattering factors and anomalous dispersion factors are contained in the SHELXTL 6.10 program library. Statistical analysis for significant differences were performed using the three-sigma limits (>3σ).
    The crystal structures of compounds 1, 2, 4, 5, and 6 have been deposited at the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre with deposition numbers 1962283, 1968141, 1968143, 1968145, and 1968213, respectively.

    Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) Spectroscopy

    1H NMR spectra were recorded in 5 mm NMR tubes using a Bruker DPX 400 MHz spectrometer at room temperature. 1H NMR chemical shifts were internally referenced to CDCl3 (7.26 ppm), [d6]DMSO (2.50 ppm) and [d7]DMF (8.03 ppm). Chemical shifts, δ, are quoted in part per million (ppm) downfield of trimethylsilane. Coupling constants, J, are reported to the nearest 0.1 Hz. The splitting patterns for the spectra assignment are abbreviated to singlet (s), doublet (d), triplet (t), quartet (q), and multiplet (m). Data processing was carried out using MestreNova, version 6.0 (Mestrelab Research, SL).

    Elemental Analysis

    Elemental analysis was carried out using a Leco analytical elemental analyzer, CHNS-932.

    Mass Spectrometry (MS)

    Low resolution mass spectra were acquired using an Expression-L compact mass spectrometer with m/z 2000 mass range equipped with an electrospray ionization (ESI) ion source and a single quadrupole analyzer. 0.1% FA methanol was used as the solvent to prepare the iridium diluted samples ([Ir] ca. 0.1 μM) and as eluent. MS analyses were carried out through direct infusion of the sample using a syringe pump.

    UV–vis Absorption Spectroscopy

    UV–vis absorption data were collected using an Agilent Cary 5000 UV–vis–NIR or an Agilent Cary 60 both equipped with temperature controller, using 1 cm path length quartz cuvettes (800 μL). Spectra were recorded at different temperatures in aqueous solutions from 200 to 600 nm. Data were processed using OriginPro version 9.0 (OriginLab, Northampton, MA).

    Dimethyl Sulfoxide Coordination

    Dimethyl sulfoxide solutions of the Ir(III) complexes (ca. 6–8 mM at 298 K) were prepared by dissolving 1–6 in [D6]DMSO. 1H NMR spectra were recorded in situ after sample preparation (data collection at ca. 5 min after dissolution) and at different times up to 24 h. Speciation of each closed-tether complex, i.e., conversion into the dimethyl sulfoxide open-tether species, was quantified by integration of a Hpy signal (an aromatic proton of the tethered pyridine) in the 1H NMR spectra. In another set of experiments, for the kinetic study by UV–vis spectroscopy, dimethyl sulfoxide solutions of the Ir(III) complexes (ca. 0.1 mM at 298 K) were prepared by dissolving 1–6 in DMSO. UV–vis absorption spectra were recorded at 298 K at different time intervals, from 200 to 600 nm. To determine the reaction rate k and the half-life t1/2, we first plotted the difference Absorption spectra (Abst – Abs0) to select the optimum wavelength at which the formation of the Ir–DMSO adduct was observed. Then we plotted the Ln of this absorbance (LnAbs) versus time, and kDMSO was obtained from the subsequent lineal fitting. Statistical analysis for significant differences were performed using the three-sigma limits (>3σ).

    Cell Culture

    MCF7 and MDA-MB-231 human breast cancer cell lines were obtained from American Type Culture Collection (ATCC). A2780 human ovarian cancer cell line, HCT116 human colorectal cancer cell line, PANC-1 human pancreatic carcinoma, and MRC-5 fibroblast-like lung normal cells were obtained from the European Collection of Cell Culture (ECACC), Public Health England (PHE). MIA PaCa-2 human pancreatic cancer cell line was kindly provided by Dr. A. Somoza (IMDEA Nanociencia, Spain). MCF7 and MIA PaCa-2 were maintained in Dulbecco’s Modified Eagle’s Medium (DMEM) Low Glucose (LabClinics), MDA-MB-231, and PANC-1 in DMEM High Glucose (LabClinics), A2780 in Roswell Park Memorial Institute (RPMI) 1640 medium (VWR), HCT116 in McCoy’s 5A medium (LabClinics), and MRC-5 in Minimum Essential Medium with Earle’s Balanced Salt Solutions (MEM (EBSS); GE Healthcare). All media were supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (Gibco, Life Technologies), 1% of 2 mM GlutaMAX-I (Gibco, Life Technologies) and 1% penicillin/streptomycin (VWR). Media for MRC-5 was also supplemented with 1% Non-Essential Amino Acids (NEAA, Merck Millipore).
    All cell lines were grown as adherent monolayers at 37 °C in a 5% CO2 humidified atmosphere. Cells were cultured for at least 7–10 days upon thawing, subcultured at approximately 70–80% confluency, and experiments were conducted on exponentially growing cells.

    Exposure to Ir(III) Compounds

    Stock solutions of the Ir(III) complexes (16 mM) were first prepared by dissolving each compound in 100% sterile DMSO (or DMF) to assist dissolution and stored at −20 °C. The compounds were then diluted in medium to get the desired concentration for treating the cells. All compounds were soluble at the maximum concentration tested in the biological assays (SI, Figure S14 and Table S1). ICP-OES was used to corroborate solubility in culture media for complex 1 as a representative example of complexes 1–6 (data not shown). Additionally, stability in aqueous solution and in saline (0.9% NaCl) at 37 °C was corroborated by means of UV–vis (SI, Figure S24). Prior to all treatments, cells were allowed to adhere for 24 or 48 h and then exposed to the test compounds. All experiments were performed in parallel with DMSO (or DMF) as vehicle control. Cisplatin, a metal-based cytotoxic agent used to treat various types of cancers in the clinic, was used as a positive control in all assays.

    Determination of IC50 Values

    For the evaluation of cellular cytotoxicity/antiproliferative activity, 5000 MCF7, A2780, MIA PaCa-2, MDA-MB-231, PANC-1 cells, 1000 HCT116 cells, and 3000 MRC-5 cells were seeded in 96-well plates (VWR) and grown for 48 h in complete medium. Solutions of the Ir(III) compounds were prepared and added to the wells to obtain a final concentration ranging from 0 to 50 (or 100 μM for the less cytotoxic complexes), and the cells were incubated for 24 h at 37 °C. Following 24 h of drug exposure, cells were washed with PBS (Fisher Scientific), supplied with fresh medium, and allowed to grow for 72 h. The protein content (proportional to living cells in culture) was measured using the sulforhodamine B (SRB) assay(46) for MCF7, A2780, MIA PaCa-2, MDA-MB-231, PANC-1, and HCT116 cells, and the MTS assay for MRC-5 cells, using a UV–visible spectrophotometer (Sinergy H4 microplate reader) at 510 and 490 nm, respectively. The percentage of surviving cells was calculated from the ratio of absorbance of treated to nontreated cells (control cells). The IC50 value was determined as the concentration of drug required to inhibit cell population growth by 50% compared to control, as a result of a combination of drug cytotoxicity and antiproliferative activity, and is presented as a mean ± CI of two to three independent experiments of four replicates each.

    Cellular Accumulation in MCF7 Cells

    MCF7 cells were seeded at a density of 2.0 × 106 cells/100 mm Petri dish in 9 mL of culture medium (three dishes were prepared per compound tested, and three untreated control dishes). After 24 h of incubation at 37 °C, cells were exposed to the Ir(III) complexes. Solutions of the Ir(III) compounds were prepared by diluting a freshly prepared stock solution (in DMSO) of the corresponding complex in media to a final concentration of 0.005, 0.25, or 1 μM. After 8 or 24 h of drug exposure at 37 °C in a 5% CO2 incubator, the drug-containing medium was removed, and the cells were washed with PBS, trypsinized, and counted using a hemocytometer. Cells were centrifuged, the media eliminated, and cell pellets were stored at −20 °C until digestion for ICP-MS analysis for 191Ir content. These experiments were all carried out in triplicate.

    ICP-MS Analysis

    ICP-MS analyses were carried out on a PerkinElmer NexION 300 ICP-MS instrument. The water used for ICP-MS analysis was purified using a Millipore Milli-Q element system. The iridium standard (SCP Science, 1000 ppm) was diluted with ultrapure water to 10 ppm. The standards for calibration were freshly prepared by diluting this stock solution with 2% HNO3 + 0.5% HCl (v/v) in ultrapure water. The concentrations used for the calibration of the instrument were 500, 50, 5, 0.5, and 0.05 ppb. Samples were diluted 1:10 with 2% HNO3 + 0.5% HCl (v/v) in ultrapure water. All calibrants and samples contained 30 ppb Re and 30 ppb Rh as internal standards.
    Cell pellets were digested as described below. To each cell pellet, 0.3 mL of ultrapure 70% HNO3 (0.3 mL; Sigma-Aldrich) were added, and the samples were transferred into Wheaton V-Vials with a PTFE-faced rubber-lined cap (Sigma-Aldrich). The vials were heated in an oven at 80 °C for 16 h to fully digest the samples and allowed to cool. Each sample was then transferred to a 15 mL tube. Then 0.3 mL of ultrapure 37% HCl (Sigma-Aldrich) was added to each tube for metal stabilization. Doubly deionized water was then added for a maximum final concentration of 5% HNO3 (suitable for ICP-MS analysis) prior to quantification of 191Ir.

    TrxR Activity Assay by DTNB Assay (in Vitro)

    An established microplate reader based assay was performed with minor modifications to determine the inhibition of TrxR. Commercially available Thioredoxin Reductase Assay Kit (Sigma-Aldrich) was used for this purpose. In this assay, the isolated rat liver TrxR enzyme catalyzes the reduction of 5,5′-dithiobis(2-nitrobenzoic)acid (DTNB) with NADPH to 5-thio-2-nitrobenzoic acid (TNB), which produces a strong yellow color, measured at 412 nm.(47) The compounds were freshly dissolved at various concentrations in media from the DMSO stock solutions. Aliquots (3 μL) of the enzyme solution were added to each well, which contained 47 μL of potassium phosphate buffer pH 7.0 and the Ir(III) compounds in graded concentrations, or vehicle (DMSO) without compounds (control probe), in a 96-well plate. The resulting solutions were incubated for 90 min (shaking every 30 min) at 37 °C. A master mixture in potassium phosphate buffer pH 7.0 and 50 mM EDTA containing DTNB and NADPH was then added (final concentration: 2 mM and 240 μM, respectively). After mixing, the formation of TNB was monitored with a microplate reader (Sinergy H4 microplate reader) at 412 nm in 31 s intervals for 10 min. The increase in TNB concentration over time followed a linear trend, and the enzymatic activity was calculated as the slopes (increase in absorbance per second) thereof. For each tested compound, the noninterference with the assay components was confirmed by a negative control experiment using an enzyme-free solution. The EC50 values were calculated as the concentration of compound decreasing the enzymatic activity of the untreated control by 50% and are given as the means and error of two or three repeated experiments in triplicate or quadruplicate.

    TrxR Activity Assay in Cell Lysates

    MCF7 cells were seeded at a density of 3.0 × 106 cells/T75 flask in 16 mL of culture medium (three flasks were prepared per compound tested, and three untreated control flasks) and incubated for 24 h at 37 °C. After that time, cells were treated with various concentrations of the Ir(III) complexes for 24 h at 37 °C, and then they were harvested and washed twice with phosphate-buffered saline (PBS). Total cellular proteins were extracted with a mixture of RIPA buffer (Thermo Scientific) and Protease Inhibitor Cocktail (MedChem Express) for 5 min on ice and subsequent scraping. The total protein content was quantified using the Pierce BCA Protein Assay Kit (Thermo Scientific). TrxR activity in cell lysates was measured by the DTNB assay. Briefly, the cell extract containing 100 μg of total proteins was incubated in a final reaction volume of 50 μL containing potassium phosphate buffer pH 7.0 for 90 min (shaking every 30 min) at 37 °C. The reaction was started by addition of NADPH and DNTB, and then the TrxR activity was detected by measurement of TNB quantity at 412 nm as described above.

    Intracellular ROS Determination by the DCFH-DA Assay

    2′,7′-Dichlorofluorescin diacetate (DCFH-DA) is a cell-permeable nonfluorescent probe. DCFH-DA is de-esterified inside the cell to DCFH, which turns to highly fluorescent 2′,7′-dichlorofluorescein, DCF, upon oxidation. DCFH is useful for the detection of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and for the determination of the degree of overall oxidative stress. ROS directly determined by the DCFH-DA assay include peroxyl, alkoxyl, NO2•, carbonate (CO3•–), and OH• radicals and peroxynitrite anion. Additionally, it can detect cellular peroxides efficiently if they are decomposed to radicals. In our protocol 50000 MCF7 cells per well were seeded in a 24-well plate and allowed to adhere for 24 h at 37 °C. Then 200 μL per well of serial dilutions of different Ir(III) complexes in medium were added to obtain the required final test concentrations of Ir(III) compounds (0–1 μM). Immediately after 90 min of exposure to Ir(III) complexes at 37 °C, the fluorescein-labeled probe DCFH-DA (20 μM) was added to each well, and incubation continued for 30 min at 37 °C in the dark. After being taken up by cells, the nonfluorescent DCFH-DA is hydrolyzed to DCFH and trapped within the cell. The nonfluorescent DCFH is then oxidized to fluorescent dichlorofluorescin (DCF) by action of cellular ROS. The DCF fluorescence intensity generated is directly proportional to total ROS levels, and it is indicative of an increase in the oxidative stress caused by iridium exposure.(48) The fluorescence was then measured on a spectrofluorometer at λex = 485 nm and λem = 535 nm. The fluorescence induction factor (fold) for each concentration of Ir(III) compounds was calculated by dividing the reading of each well by the average reading of the negative control (0 μM Ir(III)).

    Mitochondrial Transmembrane Potential Determination Using Flow Cytometry

    The change in mitochondrial membrane potential (ΔΨm) due to exposure of MCF7 cells to the Ir(III) compounds was assessed by the lipophilic cationic dye 5,5′,6,6′-tetrachloro-1,1′,3,3′-tetramethyl benzimidazol carbocyanine iodide (JC-10, abcam) and fluorescence activated cell sorting (FACS). JC-10 dye emits green fluorescence (520 nm) in its monomeric form and, as a lipophilic cation, can selectively enter into mitochondrial matrix, forming aggregates and switching color from green to red (emission at 570 nm). When apoptosis occurs, the ΔΨm is reduced and JC-10 disaggregates, which is indicated by green fluorescence (and a reduction of the red emission). Briefly, MCF7 cells were seeded at a density of 2.0 × 106 cells/100 mm Petri dish in 9 mL of culture medium (three dishes were prepared per compound tested, and three untreated control dishes) and incubated for 24 h at 37 °C. After 24 h of incubation, cells were treated with 0.25 μM of the Ir(III) complexes for 24 h at 37 °C. For positive control, carbonyl cyanide 3-chlorophenylhydrazone (CCCP) was used to depolarize the mitochondrial membrane potential. Cells were exposed at 100 μM of CCCP for 45 min. After incubation, the drug-containing medium was removed and the cells were washed with PBS, trypsinized, and centrifuged. The JC-10 staining solution was prepared by diluting the JC-10 stock solution into the assay buffer. The cell pellets were then resuspended in the JC-10 dye-loading solution and incubated at room temperature for 30 min, protected from light. After incubation, the proportion of green and red fluorescence intensity was immediately detected by a CYTOMICS FC 500 analyzer (5 colors, 1 laser, 488 nm, Beckman Coulter) using the FL1 channel for the green fluorescent monomeric signal and the FL2 channel for the orange-red fluorescent aggregated signal. Fluorescence was excited at 490 nm, and the emission was measured at 520 nm (monomeric form) and 570 (aggregate form). Flow cytometry dot plots establish four different cellular populations: F1, high red and low green fluorescence, F2 high red and green fluorescence, F3 low red and green fluorescence, and F4 low red and high green fluorescence (SI, Figure S23). The ratio between the cellular populations in F4 and F2 indicates mitochondrial depolarization by an increase in the fluorescence intensity green/red ratio. The 520 nm/570 nm emission ratio was determined from three different replicates, and the F4/F2 ratio of Ir(III)-treated or CCCP-treated cells was compared with the control cells. All the experiments were performed in triplicate.

    Statistical Analysis

    All statistical analyses were performed using R Statistical Software (version 3.3.2 (2016–10–31); R Foundation for Statistical Computing, Vienna, Austria) by one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) (*p < 0.05, **p < 0.01, and ***p < 0.001) unless otherwise stated.

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
