      37. 37
        Huang, H.; Banerjee, S.; Qiu, K.; Zhang, P.; Blacque, O.; Malcomson, T.; Paterson, M. J.; Clarkson, G. J.; Staniforth, M.; Stavros, V. G.; Gasser, G.; Chao, H.; Sadler, P. J. Targeted photoredox catalysis in cancer cells. Nat. Chem. 2019, 11 (11), 1041– 1048,  DOI: 10.1038/s41557-019-0328-4
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        37
        Targeted photoredox catalysis in cancer cells
        Huang, Huaiyi; Banerjee, Samya; Qiu, Kangqiang; Zhang, Pingyu; Blacque, Olivier; Malcomson, Thomas; Paterson, Martin J.; Clarkson, Guy J.; Staniforth, Michael; Stavros, Vasilios G.; Gasser, Gilles; Chao, Hui; Sadler, Peter J.
        Nature Chemistry (2019), 11 (11), 1041-1048CODEN: NCAHBB; ISSN:1755-4330. (Nature Research)
        Hypoxic tumors are a major problem for cancer photodynamic therapy. Here, we show that photoredox catalysis can provide an oxygen-independent mechanism of action to combat this problem. We have designed a highly oxidative Ir(III) photocatalyst, [Ir(ttpy)(pq)Cl]PF6 ([1]PF6, where 'ttpy' represents 4'-(p-tolyl)-2,2':6',2''-terpyridine and 'pq' represents 3-phenylisoquinoline), which is phototoxic towards both normoxic and hypoxic cancer cells. Complex 1 photocatalytically oxidizes 1,4-dihydronicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NADH)-an important coenzyme in living cells-generating NAD• radicals with a high turnover frequency in biol. media. Moreover, complex 1 and NADH synergistically photoreduce cytochrome c under hypoxia. D. functional theory calcns. reveal π stacking in adducts of complex 1 and NADH, facilitating photoinduced single-electron transfer. In cancer cells, complex 1 localizes in mitochondria and disrupts electron transport via NADH photocatalysis. On light irradn., complex 1 induces NADH depletion, intracellular redox imbalance and immunogenic apoptotic cancer cell death. This photocatalytic redox imbalance strategy offers a new approach for efficient cancer phototherapy.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhvVGgurfK&md5=b7774e96b85d9d648faa30c50bbea784
      38. 38
        Lu, J.; Holmgren, A. The thioredoxin antioxidant system. Free Radical Biol. Med. 2014, 66, 75– 87,  DOI: 10.1016/j.freeradbiomed.2013.07.036
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        38
        The thioredoxin antioxidant system
        Lu, Jun; Holmgren, Arne
        Free Radical Biology & Medicine (2014), 66 (), 75-87CODEN: FRBMEH; ISSN:0891-5849. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A review. The thioredoxin (Trx) system, which is composed of NADPH, thioredoxin reductase (TrxR), and thioredoxin, is a key antioxidant system in defense against oxidative stress through its disulfide reductase activity regulating protein dithiol/disulfide balance. The Trx system provides the electrons to thiol-dependent peroxidases (peroxiredoxins) to remove reactive oxygen and nitrogen species with a fast reaction rate. Trx antioxidant functions are also shown by involvement in DNA and protein repair by reducing ribonucleotide reductase, methionine sulfoxide reductases, and regulating the activity of many redox-sensitive transcription factors. Moreover, Trx systems play crit. roles in the immune response, virus infection, and cell death via interaction with thioredoxin-interacting protein. In mammalian cells, the cytosolic and mitochondrial Trx systems, in which TrxRs are high mol. wt. selenoenzymes, together with the glutathione-glutaredoxin (Grx) system (NADPH, glutathione reductase, GSH, and Grx) control the cellular redox environment. Recently, mammalian thioredoxin and glutathione systems have been found to be able to provide the electrons crossly and to serve as a backup system for each other. In contrast, bacterial TrxRs are low mol. wt. enzymes with a structure and reaction mechanism distinct from mammalian TrxR. Many bacterial species possess specific thiol-dependent antioxidant systems, and the significance of the Trx system in the defense against oxidative stress is different. Particularly, the absence of a GSH-Grx system in some pathogenic bacteria such as Helicobacter pylori, Mycobacterium tuberculosis, and Staphylococcus aureus makes the bacterial Trx system essential for survival under oxidative stress. This provides an opportunity to kill these bacteria by targeting the TrxR-Trx system.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhtlyitLzE&md5=b1b8a63b4cf4b0e8fe9476ef9b386240
      39. 39
        (a) Lord, R. M.; Hebden, A. J.; Pask, C. M.; Henderson, I. R.; Allison, S. J.; Shepherd, S. L.; Phillips, R. M.; McGowan, P. C. Hypoxia-sensitive metal beta-ketoiminato complexes showing induced single-strand DNA breaks and cancer cell death by apoptosis. J. Med. Chem. 2015, 58 (12), 4940– 4953,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.jmedchem.5b00455
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        39a
        Hypoxia-Sensitive Metal β-Ketoiminato Complexes Showing Induced Single-Strand DNA Breaks and Cancer Cell Death by Apoptosis
        Lord, Rianne M.; Hebden, Andrew J.; Pask, Christopher M.; Henderson, Imogen R.; Allison, Simon J.; Shepherd, Samantha L.; Phillips, Roger M.; McGowan, Patrick C.
        Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2015), 58 (12), 4940-4953CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
        A series of ruthenium and iridium complexes have been synthesized and characterized with 20 novel crystal structures discussed. The library of β-ketoiminato complexes has been shown to be active against MCF-7 (human breast carcinoma), HT-29 (human colon carcinoma), A2780 (human ovarian carcinoma), and A2780cis (cisplatin-resistant human ovarian carcinoma) cell lines, with selected complexes' being more than three times as active as cisplatin against the A2780cis cell line. Selected complexes were also tested against the noncancerous ARPE-19 (retinal pigment epithelial cells) cell line, in order to evaluate the complexes selectivity for cancer cells. Complexes have also been shown to be highly active under hypoxic conditions, with the activities of some complexes increasing with a decrease in O2 concn. The enzyme thioredoxin reductase is overexpressed in cancer cells, and complexes reported herein have the advantage of inhibiting this enzyme, with IC50 values measured in the nanomolar range. The anticancer activity of these complexes was further investigated to det. whether activity is due to effects on cellular growth or cell survival. The complexes were found to induce significant levels of cancer cell death by apoptosis with levels induced correlating closely with activity in chemosensitivity studies. As a possible cause of cell death, the ability of the complexes to induce damage to cellular DNA was also assessed. The complexes failed to induce double-strand DNA breaks or DNA crosslinking but induced significant levels of single-strand DNA breaks, indicating a mechanism of action different from that of cisplatin.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXntVWnsrg%253D&md5=23bc656d38c4b4c233a341538da2341f

        (b) Almodares, Z.; Lucas, S. J.; Crossley, B. D.; Basri, A. M.; Pask, C. M.; Hebden, A. J.; Phillips, R. M.; McGowan, P. C. Rhodium, iridium, and ruthenium half-sandwich picolinamide complexes as anticancer agents. Inorg. Chem. 2014, 53 (2), 727– 736,  DOI: 10.1021/ic401529u

        Rhodium, Iridium, and Ruthenium Half-Sandwich Picolinamide Complexes as Anticancer Agents
        Almodares, Zahra; Lucas, Stephanie J.; Crossley, Benjamin D.; Basri, Aida M.; Pask, Christopher M.; Hebden, Andrew J.; Phillips, Roger M.; McGowan, Patrick C.
        Inorganic Chemistry (2014), 53 (2), 727-736CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Novel rhodium, iridium, and ruthenium half-sandwich complexes contg. (N,N)-bound picolinamide ligands have been prepd. for use as anticancer agents. The complexes show promising cytotoxicities, with the presence, position, and no. of halides having a significant effect on the corresponding IC50 values. One ruthenium complex was found to be more cytotoxic than cisplatin on HT-29 and MCF-7 cells after 5 days and 1 h, resp., and it remains active with MCF-7 cells even under hypoxic conditions, making it a promising candidate for in vivo studies.

        Nordberg, J.; Arner, E. S. Reactive oxygen species, antioxidants, and the mammalian thioredoxin system. Free Radical Biol. Med. 2001, 31 (11), 1287– 1312,  DOI: 10.1016/S0891-5849(01)00724-9
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        40
        Reactive oxygen species, antioxidants, and the mammalian thioredoxin system
        Nordberg, Jonas; Arner, Elias S. J.
        Free Radical Biology & Medicine (2001), 31 (11), 1287-1312CODEN: FRBMEH; ISSN:0891-5849. (Elsevier Science Inc.)
        A review. Reactive oxygen species (ROS) are known mediators of intracellular signaling cascades. Excessive prodn. of ROS may, however, lead to oxidative stress, loss of cell function, and ultimately apoptosis or necrosis. A balance between oxidant and antioxidant intracellular systems is hence vital for cell function, regulation, and adaptation to diverse growth conditions. Thioredoxin reductase (TrxR) in conjunction with thioredoxin (Trx) is a ubiquitous oxidoreductase system with antioxidant and redox regulatory roles. In mammals, extracellular forms of Trx also have cytokine-like effects. Mammalian TrxR has a highly reactive active site selenocysteine residue resulting in a profound reductive capacity, reducing several substrates in addn. to Trx. Due to the reactivity of TrxR, the enzyme is inhibited by many clin. used electrophilic compds. including nitrosoureas, aurothioglucose, platinum compds., and retinoic acid derivs. The properties of TrxR in combination with the functions of Trx position this system at the core of cellular thiol redox control and antioxidant defense. In this review, the authors focus on the reactions of the Trx system with ROS mols. and different cellular antioxidant enzymes. The authors summarize the TrxR-catalyzed regeneration of several antioxidant compds., including ascorbic acid (vitamin C), selenium-contg. substances, lipoic acid, and ubiquinone (Q10). The general cellular effects of TrxR inhibition are also discussed. Dinitrohalobenzenes constitute a unique class of immunostimulatory TrxR inhibitors and the authors consider the immunomodulatory effects of dinitrohalobenzene compds. in view of their reactions with the Trx system.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXos1Knu7w%253D&md5=dad917a71af0cc525d71a04ee5b92e9e
      41. 41
        Rodriguez-Fanjul, V.; Lopez-Torres, E.; Mendiola, M. A.; Pizarro, A. M. Gold(III) bis(thiosemicarbazonate) compounds in breast cancer cells: Cytotoxicity and thioredoxin reductase targeting. Eur. J. Med. Chem. 2018, 148, 372– 383,  DOI: 10.1016/j.ejmech.2018.02.009
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        41
        Gold(III) bis(thiosemicarbazonate) compounds in breast cancer cells: Cytotoxicity and thioredoxin reductase targeting
        Rodriguez-Fanjul, Vanessa; Lopez-Torres, Elena; Mendiola, M. Antonia; Pizarro, Ana Maria
        European Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2018), 148 (), 372-383CODEN: EJMCA5; ISSN:0223-5234. (Elsevier Masson SAS)
        Gold(III) compds. have received increasing attention in cancer research. Three gold complexes of general formula [AuIIIL]Cl, where L is benzil bis(thiosemicarbazonate), compd. 1, benzil bis(4-methyl-3-thiosemicarbazonate), compd. 2, or benzil bis(4-cyclohexyl-3-thiosemicarbazonate), compd. 3, have been synthesized and fully characterized, including the x-ray crystal structure of compd. 3, confirming square-planar geometry around the gold(III) center. Compd. 1 showed moderate cytotoxicity and accumulation in MCF7 breast cancer cells but did not inhibit thioredoxin reductase (TrxR) activity and did not induce reactive oxygen species (ROS) prodn. Compd. 2, the least cytotoxic, is capable of modestly inhibiting TrxR activity and produced low levels of ROS in the MCF7 cell line. The most cytotoxic compd., 3, had the highest cellular accumulation and its distribution pattern showed a clear preference for the cytosol and mitochondria of MCF7 cells. It readily hampered intracellular TrxR activity leading to a dramatic alteration of the cellular redox state and to the induction of cell death.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXjt12jt78%253D&md5=b0fb5c61224cbda5f0c78f33808eba8a
      42. 42
        (a) Lee, J.; Giordano, S.; Zhang, J. Autophagy, mitochondria and oxidative stress: cross-talk and redox signalling. Biochem. J. 2012, 441 (2), 523– 540,  DOI: 10.1042/BJ20111451
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        42a
        Autophagy, mitochondria and oxidative stress: cross-talk and redox signalling
        Lee, Jisun; Giordano, Samantha; Zhang, Jianhua
        Biochemical Journal (2012), 441 (2), 523-540CODEN: BIJOAK; ISSN:0264-6021. (Portland Press Ltd.)
        A review. Reactive oxygen and nitrogen species change cellular responses through diverse mechanisms that are now being defined. At low levels, they are signalling mols., and at high levels, they damage organelles, particularly the mitochondria. Oxidative damage and the assocd. mitochondrial dysfunction may result in energy depletion, accumulation of cytotoxic mediators and cell death. Understanding the interface between stress adaptation and cell death then is important for understanding redox biol. and disease pathogenesis. Recent studies have found that one major sensor of redox signalling at this switch in cellular responses is autophagy. Autophagic activities are mediated by a complex mol. machinery including more than 30 Atg (AuTophaGy-related) proteins and 50 lysosomal hydrolases. Autophagosomes form membrane structures, sequester damaged, oxidized or dysfunctional intracellular components and organelles, and direct them to the lysosomes for degrdn. This autophagic process is the sole known mechanism for mitochondrial turnover. It has been speculated that dysfunction of autophagy may result in abnormal mitochondrial function and oxidative or nitrative stress. Emerging investigations have provided new understanding of how autophagy of mitochondria (also known as mitophagy) is controlled, and the impact of autophagic dysfunction on cellular oxidative stress. The present review highlights recent studies on redox signalling in the regulation of autophagy, in the context of the basic mechanisms of mitophagy. Furthermore, we discuss the impact of autophagy on mitochondrial function and accumulation of reactive species. This is particularly relevant to degenerative diseases in which oxidative stress occurs over time, and dysfunction in both the mitochondrial and autophagic pathways play a role.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38Xmt1Wksw%253D%253D&md5=f2d18d9c8cef7cd3b932799d22951bb4
        .
        (b) Murphy, M. P. How mitochondria produce reactive oxygen species. Biochem. J. 2009, 417 (1), 1– 13,  DOI: 10.1042/BJ20081386
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        42b
        How mitochondria produce reactive oxygen species
        Murphy, Michael P.
        Biochemical Journal (2009), 417 (1), 1-13CODEN: BIJOAK; ISSN:0264-6021. (Portland Press Ltd.)
        A review. The prodn. of reactive O species (ROS) by mammalian mitochondria is important because it underlies oxidative damage in many pathologies and contributes to retrograde redox signalling from the organelle to the cytosol and nucleus. Superoxide (O2•-) is the proximal mitochondrial ROS, and here the author outlines the principles that govern O2•- prodn. within the matrix of mammalian mitochondria. The flux of O2•- is related to the concn. of potential electron donors, the local concn. of O2, and the 2nd-order rate consts. for the reactions between them. Two modes of operation by isolated mitochondria result in significant O2•- prodn., predominantly from complex I: (1) when the mitochondria are not making ATP and consequently have a high protonmotive force (Δp) and a reduced coenzyme Q (CoQ) pool; and (2) when there is a high NADH/NAD ratio in the mitochondrial matrix. For mitochondria that are actively synthesizing ATP, and consequently have a lower Δp and NADH/NAD ratio, the extent of O2•- prodn. is far lower. The generation of O2•- within the mitochondrial matrix depends critically on Δp, the NADH/NAD and CoQH2/CoQ ratios, and the local O2 concn., which are all highly variable and difficult to measure in vivo. Consequently, it is not possible to est. O2•- generation by mitochondria in vivo from O2•--prodn. rates by isolated mitochondria, and such extrapolations in the literature are misleading. Even so, the description outlined here facilitates the understanding of factors that favor mitochondrial ROS prodn. There is a clear need to develop better methods to measure mitochondrial O2•- and H2O2 formation in vivo, as uncertainty about these values hampers studies on the role of mitochondrial ROS in pathol. oxidative damage and redox signaling.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhsV2lt77F&md5=ed7944f6fe333d32e29dd55446cd9611
      43. 43
        (a) Wang, C.; Youle, R. J. The role of mitochondria in apoptosis. Annu. Rev. Genet. 2009, 43, 95– 118,  DOI: 10.1146/annurev-genet-102108-134850
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        43a
        The role of mitochondria in apoptosis
        Wang, Chunxin; Youle, Richard J.
        Annual Review of Genetics (2009), 43 (), 95-118CODEN: ARVGB7; ISSN:0066-4197. (Annual Reviews Inc.)
        A review. Mitochondria play key roles in activating apoptosis in mammalian cells. Bcl-2 protein family members regulate the release of proteins from the space between the mitochondrial inner and outer membrane that, once in the cytosol, activate caspase proteases that dismantle cells and signal efficient phagocytosis of cell corpses. Here, the authors review the extensive literature on proteins released from the intermembrane space and consider genetic evidence for and against their roles in apoptosis activation. The authors also compare and contrast apoptosis pathways in Caenorhabditis elegans, Drosophila melanogaster, and mammals that indicate major mysteries remaining to be solved.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhsF2qtrjL&md5=1d30fe7bf06950278cf57a64d5a17d4a

        43b
        Mitochondria: dynamic organelles in disease, aging, and development
        Chan, David C.
        Cell (Cambridge, MA, United States) (2006), 125 (7), 1241-1252CODEN: CELLB5; ISSN:0092-8674. (Cell Press)
        A review. Mitochondria are the primary energy-generating system in most eukaryotic cells. Addnl., they participate in intermediary metab., Ca2+ signaling, and apoptosis. Given these well-established functions, it might be expected that mitochondrial dysfunction would give rise to a simple and predictable set of defects in all tissues. However, mitochondrial dysfunction has pleiotropic effects in multicellular organisms. Clearly, much about the basic biol. of mitochondria remains to be understood. Here, the authors discuss recent work that suggests that the dynamics (fusion and fission) of these organelles is important in development and disease.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        43c
        Mitochondria and apoptosis
        Green, Douglas R.; Reed, John C.
        Science (Washington, D. C.) (1998), 281 (5381), 1309-1312CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        A review with 57 refs. A variety of key events in apoptosis focus on mitochondria, including the release of caspase activators (such as cytochrome c), changes in electron transport, loss of mitochondrial transmembrane potential, altered cellular oxidn.-redn., and participation of pro- and antiapoptotic Bcl-2 family proteins. The different signals that converge on mitochondria to trigger or inhibit these events and their downstream effects delineate several major pathways in physiol. cell death.

        (a) He, L.; Wang, K. N.; Zheng, Y.; Cao, J. J.; Zhang, M. F.; Tan, C. P.; Ji, L. N.; Mao, Z. W. Cyclometalated iridium(III) complexes induce mitochondria-derived paraptotic cell death and inhibit tumor growth in vivo. Dalton Trans. 2018, 47 (20), 6942– 6953,  DOI: 10.1039/C8DT00783G
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        44a
        Cyclometalated iridium(III) complexes induce mitochondria-derived paraptotic cell death and inhibit tumor growth in vivo
        He, Liang; Wang, Kang-Nan; Zheng, Yue; Cao, Jian-Jun; Zhang, Ming-Fang; Tan, Cai-Ping; Ji, Liang-Nian; Mao, Zong-Wan
        Dalton Transactions (2018), 47 (20), 6942-6953CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The development of iridium complexes as potent anticancer agents has received increasing attention in recent years. In this study, four cyclometalated Ir(III) complexes with good photophys. properties and potent anticancer activity have been synthesized and characterized. They are taken up by human lung adenocarcinoma A549 cells very quickly and specifically target mitochondria. Mechanism studies reveal that one of them, namely IrM2, induces paraptosis accompanied by excessive mitochondria-derived cytoplasmic vacuoles. Meanwhile, IrM2 affects the ubiquitin-proteasome system (UPS) and mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) signaling pathways. Furthermore, IrM2 rapidly induces a series of mitochondria-related dysfunctional events, including the loss of mitochondrial membrane potential, cellular ATP depletion, mitochondrial respiration inhibition and reactive oxygen species (ROS) elevation. The rapid loss of mitochondrial functions, elevation of ROS and impairment of the UPS induced by IrM2 lead to the collapse of mitochondria and the subsequent cytoplasmic vacuolation before the cells are ready to start the mechanisms of apoptosis and/or autophagy. Among the ROS, superoxide anion radicals play a crit. role in IrM2-mediated cell death. In vivo studies reveal that IrM2 can significantly inhibit tumor growth in a mouse model. This work gives useful insights into the design and anticancer mechanisms of new metal-based anticancer agents.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXnsFCmtbY%253D&md5=9b094ef5dc37671e593a26874795a5d3
        .
        (b) Cao, J. J.; Tan, C. P.; Chen, M. H.; Wu, N.; Yao, D. Y.; Liu, X. G.; Ji, L. N.; Mao, Z. W. Targeting cancer cell metabolism with mitochondria-immobilized phosphorescent cyclometalated iridium(III) complexes. Chem. Sci. 2017, 8 (1), 631– 640,  DOI: 10.1039/C6SC02901A
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        44b
        Targeting cancer cell metabolism with mitochondria-immobilized phosphorescent cyclometalated iridium(III) complexes
        Cao, Jian-Jun; Tan, Cai-Ping; Chen, Mu-He; Wu, Na; Yao, De-Yang; Liu, Xing-Guo; Ji, Liang-Nian; Mao, Zong-Wan
        Chemical Science (2017), 8 (1), 631-640CODEN: CSHCCN; ISSN:2041-6520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Cancer cell metab. is reprogrammed to sustain the high metabolic demands of cell proliferation. Recently, emerging studies have shown that mitochondrial metab. is a potential target for cancer therapy. Herein, four mitochondria-targeted phosphorescent cyclometalated iridium(III) complexes have been designed and synthesized. Complexes 2 and 4, contg. reactive chloromethyl groups for mitochondrial fixation, show much higher cytotoxicity than complexes 1 and 3 without mitochondria-immobilization properties against the cancer cells screened. Further studies show that complexes 2 and 4 induce caspase-dependent apoptosis through mitochondrial damage, cellular ATP depletion, mitochondrial respiration inhibition and reactive oxygen species (ROS) elevation. The phosphorescence of complexes 2 and 4 can be utilized to monitor the perinuclear clustering of mitochondria in real time, which provides a reliable and convenient method for in situ monitoring of the therapeutic effect and gives hints for the investigation of anticancer mechanisms. Genome-wide transcriptional anal. shows that complex 2 exerts its anticancer activity through metab. repression and multiple cell death signalling pathways. Our work provides a strategy for the construction of highly effective anticancer agents targeting mitochondrial metab. through rational modification of phosphorescent iridium complexes.

        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        44c
        Oncosis-inducing cyclometalated iridium(III) complexes
        Guan, Ruilin; Chen, Yu; Zeng, Leli; Rees, Thomas W.; Jin, Chengzhi; Huang, Juanjuan; Chen, Zhe-Sheng; Ji, Liangnian; Chao, Hui
        Chemical Science (2018), 9 (23), 5183-5190CODEN: CSHCCN; ISSN:2041-6520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Oncosis is a non-apoptotic form of programmed cell death (PCD), which differs from apoptosis in both morphol. changes and inner pathways, and might hold the key to defeating a major obstacle in cancer therapy - drug-resistance, which is often a result of the intrinsic apoptosis resistance of tumors. However, despite the fact that the term "oncosis" was coined and used much earlier than apoptosis, little effort has been made to discover new drugs which can initiate this form of cell death, in comparison to drugs inducing apoptosis or any other type of PCD. So herein, we present the synthesis of a series of mitochondria-targeting cyclometalated Ir(III) complexes, which activated the oncosis-specific protein porimin and calpain in cisplatin-resistant cell line A549R, and detd. their cytotoxicity against a wide range of drug-resistant cancer types. To the best of our knowledge, these complexes are the very first metallo-components to induce oncosis in drug-resistant cancer cells.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXosl2lsrs%253D&md5=66eb866af7d165a6887ac64bd2b894c9
      45. 45
        Millett, A. J.; Habtemariam, A.; Romero-Canelon, I.; Clarkson, G. J.; Sadler, P. J. Contrasting anticancer activity of half-sandwich iridium(III) complexes bearing functionally ddiverse 2-phenylpyridine ligands. Organometallics 2015, 34 (11), 2683– 2694,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.organomet.5b00097
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        45
        Contrasting Anticancer Activity of Half-Sandwich Iridium(III) Complexes Bearing Functionally Diverse 2-Phenylpyridine Ligands
        Millett, Adam J.; Habtemariam, Abraha; Romero-Canelon, Isolda; Clarkson, Guy J.; Sadler, Peter J.
        Organometallics (2015), 34 (11), 2683-2694CODEN: ORGND7; ISSN:0276-7333. (American Chemical Society)
        We report the synthesis, characterization, and antiproliferative activity of 15 iridium(III) half-sandwich complexes of the type [(η5-Cp*)Ir(2-(R'-phenyl)-R-pyridine)Cl] bearing either an electron-donating (-OH, -CH2OH, -CH3) or electron-withdrawing (-F, -CHO, -NO2) group at various positions on the 2-phenylpyridine (2-PhPy) chelating ligand giving rise to six sets of structural isomers. The X-ray crystal structures of [(η5-Cp*)Ir(2-(2'-fluorophenyl)pyridine)Cl] (1) and [(η5-Cp*)Ir(2-(4'-fluorophenyl)pyridine)Cl] (2) exhibit the expected "piano-stool" configuration. DFT calcns. showed that substituents caused only localized effects on the electrostatic potential surface of the chelating 2-PhPy ligand of the complexes. Hydrolysis of all complexes is rapid, but readily reversed by addn. of NaCl. The complexes show preferential binding to 9-ethylguanine over 9-methyladenine and are active catalysts for the oxidn. of NADH to NAD+. Antiproliferative activity expts. in A2780 ovarian, MCF-7 breast, A549 lung, and HCT116 colon cancer cell lines showed IC50 values ranging from 1 to 89 μM, with the most potent complex, [(η5-Cp*)Ir(2-(2'-methylphenyl)pyridine)Cl] (13) (A2780 IC50 = 1.18 μM), being 10× more active than the parent, [(η5-Cp*)Ir(2-phenylpyridine)Cl], and 2× more active than [(η5-CpxPh)Ir(2-phenylpyridine)Cl]. Intriguingly, contrasting biol. activities are obsd. between structural isomers despite exhibiting similar chem. reactivity. For pairs of structural isomers both the nature and position of the functional group can affect the hydrophobicity of the complex. An increase in hydrophobicity resulted in enhanced cellular-iridium accumulation in A2780 ovarian cells, which generally gave rise to an increase in potency. The structural isomers [(η5-Cp*)Ir(2-(4'-fluorophenyl)pyridine)Cl] (2) and [(η5-Cp*)Ir(2-phenyl-5-fluoropyridine)Cl] (4) preferentially localized in the cytosol > membrane and particulate > nucleus > cytoskeleton. This work highlights the strong dependence of biol. behavior on the nature and position of the substituent on the chelating ligand and shows how this class of organometallic anticancer complexes can be fine-tuned to increase their potency without using extended cyclopentadienyl systems.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXlt1Wltbs%253D&md5=3257bbc7c2587b1338d3e960df64f4be
      46. 46
        Vichai, V.; Kirtikara, K. Sulforhodamine B colorimetric assay for cytotoxicity screening. Nat. Protoc. 2006, 1 (3), 1112– 1116,  DOI: 10.1038/nprot.2006.179
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        46
        Sulforhodamine B colorimetric assay for cytotoxicity screening
        Vichai, Vanicha; Kirtikara, Kanyawim
        Nature Protocols (2006), 1 (3), 1112-1116CODEN: NPARDW; ISSN:1750-2799. (Nature Publishing Group)
        The sulforhodamine B (SRB) assay is used for cell d. detn., based on the measurement of cellular protein content. The method described here was optimized for the toxicity screening of compds. to adherent cells in a 96-well format. After an incubation period, cell monolayers are fixed with 10% (wt/vol) trichloroacetic acid and stained for 30 min, after which the excess dye is removed by washing repeatedly with 1% (vol/vol) acetic acid. The protein-bound dye is dissolved in 10 mM Tris base soln. for OD detn. at 510 nm using a microplate reader. The results are linear over a 20-fold range of cell nos. and the sensitivity is comparable to those of fluorometric methods. The method not only allows a large no. of samples to be tested within a few days, but also requires only simple equipment and inexpensive reagents. The SRB assay is therefore an efficient and highly cost-effective method for screening.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XhtFOitL3O&md5=7173035a1f9eb3f02dd7f1a947bca659
      47. 47
        (a) Hill, K. E.; McCollum, G. W.; Burk, R. F. Determination of thioredoxin reductase activity in rat liver supernatant. Anal. Biochem. 1997, 253 (1), 123– 125,  DOI: 10.1006/abio.1997.2373
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        47a
        Determination of thioredoxin reductase activity in rat liver supernatant
        Hill, Kristina E.; McCollum, Gary W.; Burk, Raymond F.
        Analytical Biochemistry (1997), 253 (1), 123-125CODEN: ANBCA2; ISSN:0003-2697. (Academic Press)
        A simple assay based on the direct redn. of 5,5'-dithiobis(2-nitrobenzoic acid) (DTNB) by thioredoxin reductase has been used to qual. measure the enzyme activity during purifn. However, it was not suitable for quant. detn. of thioredoxin reductase because it did not correct for DTNB redn. by other enzymes or endogenous thiols in tissue. Here, the DTNB-based assay is modified to allow for correction of the non-specific DTNB redn. Thioredoxin reductase, like most other selenoenzymes, is sensitive to inhibition by gold. Thus, measurement of the enzyme activity in the absence and presence of gold thioglucose allows correction for non-thioredoxin reductase-dependent DTNB redn. Thioredoxin reductase levels were detd. in liver supernatant of control and selenium-deficient rats. Selenium deficiency caused a decrease in liver thioredoxin reductase activity to 10% of that in control liver, a result that is comparable to that obtained by the insulin-based assay.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2sXnsVegt74%253D&md5=748b9ea85d71a331ac70296f9967f7d1
        .
        (b) Holmgren, A.; Bjornstedt, M., Thioredoxin and Thioredoxin Reductase. In Methods in Enzymology; Academic Press: 1995; Vol. 252, pp 199– 208.
        Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      48. 48
        (a) Mahalingaiah, P. K.; Singh, K. P. Chronic oxidative stress increases growth and tumorigenic potential of MCF-7 breast cancer cells. PLoS One 2014, 9 (1), e87371  DOI: 10.1371/journal.pone.0087371
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        48a
        Chronic oxidative stress increases growth and tumorigenic potential of MCF-7 breast cancer cells
        Mahalingaiah, Prathap Kumar S.; Singh, Kamaleshwar P.
        PLoS One (2014), 9 (1), e87371/1-e87371/10, 10 pp.CODEN: POLNCL; ISSN:1932-6203. (Public Library of Science)
        Accumulating evidence suggests that exposures to elevated levels of either endogenous estrogen or environmental estrogenic chems. are assocd. with breast cancer development and progression. These natural or synthetic estrogens are known to produce reactive oxygen species (ROS) and increased ROS has been implicated in both cellular apoptosis and carcinogenesis. Though there are several studies on direct involvement of ROS in cellular apoptosis using short-term exposure model, there is no exptl. evidence to directly implicate chronic exposure to ROS in increased growth and tumorigenicity of breast cancer cells. Therefore, the objective of this study was to evaluate the effects of chronic oxidative stress on growth, survival and tumorigenic potential of MCF-7 breast cancer cells. MCF-7 cells were exposed to exogenous hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) as a source of ROS at doses of 25 μM and 250 μM for acute (24 h) and chronic period (3 mo) and their effects on cell growth/survival and tumorigenic potential were evaluated. The results of cell count, MTT and cell cycle anal. showed that while acute exposure inhibits the growth of MCF-7 cells in a dose-dependent manner, the chronic exposure to H2O2-induced ROS leads to increased cell growth and survival of MCF-7 cells. This was further confirmed by gene expression anal. of cell cycle and cell survival related genes. Significant increase in no. of soft agar colonies, up-regulation of pro-metastatic genes VEGF, WNT1 and CD44, whereas down-regulation of anti-metastatic gene E-Cadherin in H2O2 treated MCF-7 cells obsd. in this study further suggests that persistent exposure to oxidative stress increases tumorigenic and metastatic potential of MCF-7 cells. Since many chemotherapeutic drugs are known to induce their cytotoxicity by increasing ROS levels, the results of this study are also highly significant in understanding the mechanism for adaptation to ROS-induced toxicity leading to acquired chemotherapeutic resistance in breast cancer cells.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXlsVWlurk%253D&md5=20555f0961c5290619ec209306705187
        .
        (b) LeBel, C. P.; Ischiropoulos, H.; Bondy, S. C. Evaluation of the probe 2′,7′-dichlorofluorescin as an indicator of reactive oxygen species formation and oxidative stress. Chem. Res. Toxicol. 1992, 5 (2), 227– 231,  DOI: 10.1021/tx00026a012
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        48b
        Evaluation of the probe 2',7'-dichlorofluorescin as an indicator of reactive oxygen species formation and oxidative stress
        LeBel, Carl P.; Ischiropoulos, Harry; Bondy, Stephen C.
        Chemical Research in Toxicology (1992), 5 (2), 227-31CODEN: CRTOEC; ISSN:0893-228X.
        The use of dichlorofluorescin (DCFH) as a measure of reactive oxygen species was studied in aq. media. Hydrogen peroxide oxidized DCFH to fluorescent dichlorofluorescein (DCF), and the oxidn. was amplified by the addn. of ferrous iron. Hydrogen peroxide-induced DCF formation in the presence of ferrous iron was completely inhibited by deferoxamine and partially inhibited by EDTA, but was augmented by diethylenetriaminepentaacetic acid. Iron peroxide-induced oxidn. of DCFH was partially inhibited by catalase but not by horseradish peroxidase. Nonchelated iron peroxide oxidn. of DCFH was partially inhibited by several hydroxyl radical scavengers, but independent of the scavenger concn., and this suggests that free hydroxyl radical is not involved in the oxidn. of DCFH in this system. Superoxide anion did not directly oxidize DCFH. Data suggest that H2O2-Fe2+-derived oxidant is mainly responsible for the nonenzymic oxidn. of DCFH. In addn., peroxidase alone and oxidants formed during the redn. of H2O2 by peroxidase oxidize DCFH. Since DCFH oxidn. may be derived from several reactive intermediates, interpretation of specific reactive oxygen species involved in biol. systems should be approached with caution. However, DCFH remains an attractive probe as an overall index of oxidative stress in toxicol. phenomena.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK38XhsVGmtr8%253D&md5=6a1b478d7cde37d20e8ff349f6f8f186
